questions.text: 1. The number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year is:
questions.solution:
General fertility rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group in a given year.

GFR = [(Number of live births in an area during year) / (Mid-year female population in reproductive age of 15-44 or 49 in same area in same year)] x 1000

It is a good measure of fertility but its disadvantage is that not all women in that area in the reproductive age group would have been exposed to childbirth.

Other options:

Option B: Gross reproduction rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming there is no mortality.

Option C: Net reproduction rate is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

Option D: Total fertility rate is the sum of the age-specific fertility rates of women in each five-year age group from 15 to 44 or 49 years.

Pearl PM1709: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

* It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory

* India, as per the SRS report 2023, had a birth rate of 18.4 per 1000 population



General Fertility Rate

* It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate

* The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth



Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.



Total Fertility Rate

* It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5 (considering an age interval of 5 years; for example, 15-19, 20-24, etc)

* This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size



Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.



Net Reproduction Rate

* It is a demographic indicator

* NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm

* If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: 2. An elderly patient presents with fever and left-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal examination reveals a tender, ill-defined mass in the left lower quadrant. An abdominal CT scan reveals stage Ib diverticulitis. What is the stage indicative of?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly patient presenting with fever, left-sided abdominal pain, a tender and ill-defined mass in the left lower quadrant, and stage Ib diverticulitis on an abdominal CT is suggestive of complicated diverticulitis with a pericolic abscess.

Diverticula are saccular outpouchings of the bowel wall. True diverticula are usually rare and congenital and contain all the layers of the bowel wall. The majority of colonic diverticula are false diverticula in which the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated through the colonic wall.

Diverticulosis refers to the presence of diverticula without inflammation. Diverticulitis refers to inflammation and infection associated with a diverticulum. Peridiverticular and pericolic infection results from a perforation of a diverticulum, which leads to contamination, inflammation, and infection.

Most patients with diverticulitis present with left-sided abdominal pain, with or without fever, and leukocytosis. A mass may be palpable in the left lower quadrant with associated tenderness and is almost invariably a pericolic inflammatory mass or abscess. 

CT scan is useful for diagnosis and defining pericolic inflammation, phlegmon, or abscess. The Hinchey classification for acute diverticulitis has been variously adapted and modified and is useful in outlining successive stages of severity. The modified Hinchey classification system is as follows:

Stage

Clinical diagnosis

 CT finding

0

Mild clinical diverticulitis

 Diverticula with colonic wall thickening (Option A)

Ia

Confined pericolic inflammation—phlegmon

Pericolic soft tissue changes

Ib

Confined pericolic or mesocolic abscess

Ia changes + pericolic or mesocolic abscess

II

Pelvic, distant intraabdominal or intraperitoneal abscess

Ia changes + distant abscess, usually deep pelvic (Option C)

III

Generalized purulent peritonitis

Localized or generalized ascites, pneumoperitoneum, peritoneal thickening (Option D)

IV

Fecal peritonitis

Same as stage III

questions.text: 3. Which of the following structures and their location in the middle ear is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Canal for facial nerve - medial wall

questions.solution:
The canal for tensor tympani is located on the anterior wall, not on the roof.

The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoideum.

The image below shows the tegmen tympani.



The middle ear has a roof, floor, and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

* Roof: Formed by tegmen tympani bone

* Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone

* Anterior wall: Structures related are

* Eustachian tube

* Canal of tensor tympani

* Internal carotid artery

* Posterior wall: It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is present above the pyramid. The posterior sinus, also known as the facial recess, is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the VII nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani, and above by the fossa incudis. Intact canal wall techniques use this for middle ear access.

* Medial wall: It is formed by the labyrinth and it presents as a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to:

* Oval window

* round window

* Processus cochleoriformis

* Horizontal semicircular canal

* Canal of the facial nerve

* Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called the scutum.

The following image shows the relations of middle ear:

questions.text: 4. A scatter diagram is drawn to study:

choices.text: Mean and median values of extrapolated data

questions.solution:
Scatter plots are types of statistical maps that are used to study the correlation between two quantitative variables. In scatter plots or scatter diagrams, the pattern made by plotted points along the two axes indicates a possible relationship.

* If the dots cluster along a straight line, then the relationship is linear.

* If there is no cluster, then there might be no relationship at all.

Below is an example of a scatter diagram:



Pearl PM0932: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

* A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.

* The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.

* The following image shows a histogram.



2. Bar Chart

* It is also called a bar graph.

* It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.

* The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.

* Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.



3. Pie Charts

* Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.

* The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.



4. Frequency polygons

* Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.

* In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.



5. Ogive

* A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.



6. Line chart

* It is also called a line diagram or line graph.

* Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: 5. A primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with pre-eclampsia. All of the following changes are seen in this condition except______
questions.solution:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increased production of soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase. (SFlt-1)

Pre-eclampsia is characterized by the development of hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation along with proteinuria. 

Endothelial dysfunction occurs due to the failure of the second wave of extra-villous trophoblasts migration into spiral arteries. This results in decreased blood supply to the fetoplacental unit. As a result, the blood vessels have high resistance, high pressure, and low blood flow.

An imbalance exists in the various components of prostaglandins, with a deficiency of vasodilator prostaglandin (PGI2)(Option A) from vascular endothelium and an increased synthesis of vasoconstrictor thromboxane (TXA2) in platelets(Option C). There is also heightened sensitivity to the blood pressure-raising agent angiotensin-II. Nitric oxide, which plays a vital role in relaxing vascular smooth muscles, inhibiting platelet aggregation, and preventing blood clot formation in placental vessels, becomes deficient, contributing to hypertension.(Option B)

Endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, synthesized by endothelial cells, adds to the cause of hypertension, along with inflammatory mediators like cytokines (tumor necrosis factor, interleukins, etc.) causing endothelial damage. Abnormal lipid metabolism leads to increased oxidative stress and further endothelial injury. Platelet and neutrophil activation, cytokines, superoxide radical production, and endothelial damage form a detrimental cycle.

An imbalance of angiogenic and antiangiogenic proteins in the placental vascular bed results in an overproduction of two antiangiogenic factors from the trophoblastic tissue, namely soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase I (SFlt-1) and soluble endoglin. These factors cause dysfunction in the endothelial cells. Other contributing factors include the mutation of factor V Leiden, which elevates the risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: 6. The enzyme pyruvate carboxylase is allosterically activated and inhibited by:
questions.solution:
The enzyme pyruvate carboxylase is allosterically activated by acetyl-CoA and inhibited by ADP.

An allosteric enzyme is one that has one catalytic site for the substrate to bind and another allosteric site where the modifier binds. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme, called allosteric activation, or inhibit the activity of the enzyme, called allosteric inhibition. In allosteric activation, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier, and in allosteric inhibition, it is known as the negative modifier.

Pyruvate carboxylase catalyses the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate under allosteric activation of acetyl-CoA. So, Acetyl CoA can determine the amount of oxaloacetate formed from Pyruvate, which is formed via Glycolysis. 

ADP acts as an allosteric inhibitor, preventing the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate.

Other options:

Option A: Acetyl CoA-carboxylase is allosterically activated by citrate and inhibited by Acyl CoA and catalyses the conversion of Acetyl CoA to Malonyl CoA

Option C: Phosphofructokinase is activated by AMP and inhibited by ATP. It catalyses the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate during glycolysis.

Option D: Aspartate transcarbamoylase is the catalyst for the first step in the synthesis of pyrimidines, the formation of carbamoyl aspartic acid from carbamoyl phosphate and aspartic acid. It is allosterically activated by ATP and inhibited by CTP

questions.text: 7. A 55-year-old man with a history of prosthetic valve surgery comes to the clinic for evaluation of fever. On examination, a new-onset systolic murmur is heard in the mitral region and dark-red petechiae are seen in the nail beds of his hand. The following finding is seen on fundoscopy. Which of the following can be most likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Fish-mouth stenosis of the mitral valve
Multiple, large, friable vegetations on heart valves

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever with a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region in a patient who underwent prosthetic valve surgery, along with the fundoscopy finding of Roth's spots (exudative hemorrhagic lesions), is strongly suggestive of infective endocarditis, characterised by multiple, large, friable vegetations on heart valves.

Clinical features of endocarditis include fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias. Cardiac murmurs, valvular insufficiency, and heart failure may also be present.

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

* Petechiae are common but nonspecific findings.

* Purulent purpura

* Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous nodules that are usually found on the distal pads of the digits.

* Janeway lesions are non-tender maculae on the palms and soles.

* Roth spots are relatively rare retinal haemorrhages with small, clear centres.

* Splinter haemorrhages are seen in the nails of this patient. Subungual splinter haemorrhages are classically identified as dark-red, linear petechiae in the nail bed. 

* Splenic and cerebral abscess

Diagnosis is made using modified Duke's criteria, and treatment is done using long-term (6 weeks or more) antibiotic therapy and/or valve replacement

Other options:

Option A: Fish-mouth or “buttonhole” stenoses as seen in rheumatic mitral stenosis due to calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures.

The image below shows the fish-mouth appearance seen in mitral stenosis:



Option B: Brown atrophy can be seen in the liver and heart. It occurs due to the accumulation of a brown pigment called lipochrome or lipofuscin in large amounts due to normal aging process.

Option D: Calcified masses on the outflow surfaces of the cusps of aortic valves are seen in calcific aortic stenosis.

Pearl PM2026: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

* Pathologic criteria

* Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.



Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

* Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR

* If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: 8. Soft contact lens is made up of
questions.solution:
Soft lenses are made up of HEMA– hydroxyethyl methacrylate.

Pearl PM0345: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

* Hard lenses:

* Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)

* They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.

* Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:

* Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)

* Soft lenses:

* Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: 9. Freebasing is done with which of the following substances:
questions.solution:
Freebasing is done using cocaine.

Freebasing is a form of smoking cocaine that refers to the mixing of a street variant of cocaine (crack) with a pure form for increased effects. Street cocaine is often diluted with sugar or procaine and thus varies often in purity. Methods of cocaine abuse include:

* Snorting or tooting: Most common, Least dangerous and involves inhaling finely chopped powder via the nose

* Injection: Subcutaneous or Intravenous

* Smoking (Freebasing)

Other street names for cocaine include White Lady, Coke, Blow, Snow, and Rocks.

Pearl PM2115: Common names of Drugs of abuse

Drug of abuse Common name
Cocaine White lady, Coke, Blow, Snow
Cannabis Weed, Pot, Reefer, Ganja, Mary Jane, Hash, Indian hemp
Heroin Smack, Dope, Brown sugar, Snowball
Ketamine Vitamin K, Special K, Super K
LSD Acid
Methamphetamine Ice, Meth, Crystal,
MDMA Ecstasy
Phencyclidine Angel dust


 

Forms of cannabis:

Bhang: Decoction prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot

Majoon: Sweet prepared from bhang

Ganja: Prepared from flower tops of female plant and smoked

Hashish/Charas: Most potent; resin exudate from leaves and stem that's smoked

questions.text: 10. All of the following local anesthetics have a long duration of action, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the given options have a long duration of action except lidocaine, which has an intermediate duration of action.

Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that is widely used wherever an agent with an intermediate duration of action is needed. When given along with epinephrine, lidocaine's action is prolonged because of decreased absorption. 

Tetracaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine are long-acting local anesthetics.

Local anesthetics are agents that cause a reversible loss of sensory/motor paralysis in a restricted area. Clinically, they can be used for:

* topical - direct application of the aqueous solution to mucous membranes

* infiltration - direct injection of agent to tissue

* field block - subcutaneous injection to anesthetize region distal to the injection

* nerve block - injection directly onto peripheral nerves/ nerve plexus 

* intravenous (Bier's block) - relies on vasculature to anesthetize nerve trunk and endings

* spinal - injected into CSF in lumbar space

* epidural - injected into epidural space

Pearl PM0531: Classification of local anesthetics based on duration of action

Short duration of action ( 20-45 minutes):

* Procaine

* Chloroprocaine

Intermediate duration ( 60-120 minutes):

* Lidocaine

* Mepivacaine

* Prilocaine

Long duration (400-450 minutes):

* Tetracaine

* Bupivacaine

* Ropivacaine

* Etidocaine

Pearl PM0513: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

* Naturally occurring

* Vasoconstrictor

* 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

* Safest

* Causes maximum methemoglobinemia

* Suitable for Bier’s IV block

* EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

* Long-acting

* Most cardiotoxic

* Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

* Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

* LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia

* 1st synthetic LA

* Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

Pearl PM0532: Classification of Local Anesthetics based on the Potency

* Low Potency - Procaine

* Intermediate Potency

* Mepivacaine

* Prilocaine

* Chloroprocaine

* Lidocaine

* High Potency

* Tetracaine

* Bupivacaine

* Etidocaine

questions.text: 11. A patient hit by a motorist underwent an X-ray, shown below. What is the diagnosis and type of fracture as per Tile's classification?

choices.text: Open book fracture, rotationally stable fracture
Open book fracture, rotationally unstable fracture

questions.solution:
The fracture shown in the image is an open-book fracture of the pelvis, which is a rotationally unstable fracture as per Tile's classification.

The given vignette describes a man who underwent a high-energy traumatic injury in the form of RTA, where he was hit by a vehicle. Such an impact can cause pelvic fractures like open-book fractures. Open book fractures are also called pelvic diastatic fractures, whereby the symphysis pubis between the two pubic bones is disrupted. It may also be associated with concomitant pubic ramus and sacroiliac fractures.

On examination, the lower limbs may be externally rotated, and on palpation, a gap may be felt at the pubic symphysis. A pelvic compression test is positive. Associated injuries may be present, most commonly urethral rupture, presenting as blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, a perineal hematoma, and bladder distension.

Other injuries seen are bladder rupture, injury to the vagina/rectum, major vessel injury which presents as hypotension, lumbosacral nerve injury, and rarely diaphragmatic rupture. Diagnosis of the fracture is made by a good-quality pelvis with both hips AP view X-ray complemented by investigations for the complications.

Classification of pelvic fractures by Tile is given below:

Type Stability Fracture
A Stable

A1-fracture pelvis not involving the ring

A2-stable, minimally displaced ring fracture
B Rotationally unstable, vertically stable

B1- Open-book fracture

B2-Ipsilateral lateral compression

B3-C/L lateral compression(Bucket-Handle fracture)
C Rotationally and vertically unstable

C1-Unilateral

C2-Bilateral

C3-associated acetabular fracture


Treatment of any open book fracture first involves stabilization of the patient and treatment of the shock followed by emergency management of any associated complications. This is followed by treatement of the fracture per se.

For open book fractures, if the opening up of the pelvis is <2.5 cm, absolute bed rest for 3-4 weeks with analgesics is prescribed. Full mobility is usually regained in 6-8 weeks as gradual weight bearing is exercised. For opening up >2.5 cm, any of three methods may be attempted:

* External fixation: using Schanz pins, rods, and metal frames

* Internal fixation: symphysis fixed with plate

* Hammock-sling traction (not preferred nowadays)

The image given below shows an Open-book fracture:



Other Options: 

Option A and B: Malgaigne fracture is a type of pelvic fracture where there is a fracture of the pubic ramus anteriorly and sacroiliac joint or ilium posteriorly, on the same side. It is a form of pelvic ring disruption and is rotationally unstable. The fracture is shown below:

questions.text: 12. Ujjawala Scheme includes all the following except:
questions.solution:
Ujjawala Scheme does not include remuneration.

Ujjawala Scheme was begun to comprehensively fight trafficking of victims for commercial sexual exploitation. It was launched by the Ministry of Women and Child Development in 2007.

It involves:

* Prevent trafficking of women and children by formation of vigilance groups and awareness groups

* Rescue and safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation

* Rehabilitation of victims with provision of shelter, amenities, medical and legal care

* Re-integration of these victims into the society

* Repatriation of the cross-border victims to their country of origin.

questions.text: 13. A preterm baby in the neonatal intensive care unit is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She is found to have stage 2 ROP in zone I with no plus disease. What is the recommended treatment for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for ROP stage 2 in zone I (categorized as type 2/low-risk ROP) is careful observation and follow-up.

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

* Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.

* Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation

* Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.

* Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment

* Stage 5- total retinal detachment

* 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image) Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata. Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

These zones are shown in the image below:



Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

* Any ROP + plus disease

* Stage 3 ROP in zone I

* Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

* Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease

* Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

    Stage 1   Stage 2   Stage 3
Zone I Observation Observation Treatment
Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment


 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.



Pearl PM2021: Potential adverse reactions to drugs administered in infants

Drug Side effect
Oxygen Retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia
Chloramphenicol Gray baby syndrome, bone marrow suppression
Vitamin K analogs Jaundice
Tetracycline Enamel hypoplasia
Sodium bicarbonate Intraventricular hemorrhage
Amphotericin Anuric renal failure
Indomethacin Oliguria, hyponatremia, intestinal perforation
Aminoglycosides Deafness, renal toxicity
Erythromycin Pyloric stenosis
Morphine Hypotension, urine retention

questions.text: 14. A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp. On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of tinea capitis and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

* Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia

* Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.

* Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

* Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.

* Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor. This fungus causes infection of the stratum corneum, leading to discolored or depigmented macules over the thorax, abdomen, and upper limbs.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: 15. A 7-year-old girl was brought with complaints of ataxia and signs of increased intracranial tension. A report of the radiological investigation which is performed on her is given below. What is this investigation used to assess/based on?
questions.solution:
The investigation on which the report shown in the image above is magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy. It is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.



Other options:

Option B: Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technique in which contrast within the image is based on the microscopic motion of water. Thus, it is more sensitive to early changes of cytotoxic or vasogenic damage at the cellular level than traditional MRI measurements such as T1 or T2 relaxation rates.

Option C: The blood oxygen level–dependent (BOLD) effect forms the basis for fMRI (functional MRI).

Option D: Microhemorrhages are detected by the susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) technique of MRI.

questions.text: 16. Which of the following is not a part of the four symptoms screening for TB in a 8 year old child with HIV ?

choices.text: History of contact with a TB case

questions.solution:
Night sweats are not a part of the symptoms used for screening for TB in a 8 year old child with HIV.

The four symptoms (4S) screening for children less than 10 years of age with HIV includes:

* Current cough

* Fever

* Weight loss or failure to gain weight

* History of contact with a TB case

Intensified case finding is done at ART centers for active TB amongst patients with HIV. This enables early diagnosis and treatment of TB, and also reduces transmission from one patient to another. People living with HIV (PLHIV) are screened for TB during their visits to the ART center using the four symptoms (4S) screening. The symptoms considered differ between children below 10 years of age (given above) and adults and adolescents (more than 10 years of age). For adults and adolescents, the following symptoms are considered:

* Current cough

* Fever

* Weight loss

* Night sweats

If the PLHIV is found to be positive for any of these symptoms, they are referred for CB-NAAT for the microbiological confirmation of TB.

questions.text: 17. Which of the following is not a cause of Acute Demyelinating Encephalomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Post-traumatic is not a cause of ADEM (Acute Demyelinating Encephalomyelitis); rather, it is a cause of transverse myelitis.

Causes of ADEM (Acute Demyelinating Encephalomyelitis):

* Parainfectious: Rubella, mumps, herpes zoster, herpes simplex, influenza, EBV, coxsackievirus, Borrelia burgdorferi, mycoplasma, and leptospira.

* Post-vaccination: Rabies, pertussis, rubella, diphtheria, and measles.

* Post-drug administration: sulfonamides, para-aminosalicylic acid/streptomycin.

questions.text: 18. Exception to the rule of professional secrecy is allowed under the following circumstances except
questions.solution:
Interest of relatives is not an exception for Professional secrecy.

Exceptions to the rule of  Professional secrecy includes :

"No CIVIC SINS "

* No – Notifiable diseases, birth, death

* C -  suspected Crime

* I – self Interest

* C - Court of law

questions.text:
19. A primigravida at 36 weeks with reduced perception of fetal movements undergoes a biophysical profile test with the following results. What will be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

* NST- 3 accelerations in 30 mins, with ≥ 15 bpm above baseline, lasting ≥ 15 seconds

* 2 episodes of breathing movements

* 3 amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2x2 cm each

* 1 limb flexion & extension noted

* 1 gross body movement
questions.solution:
The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient is to do NST weekly.

The biophysical profile of this pregnant woman is interpreted as:

* A reactive NST = 2

* 2 episodes of breathing movements = 2

* 3 amniotic fluid pockets measuring 2x2 cm each = 2

* 1 flexion & extension movement for muscle tone = 2

* 1 gross body movement = 0 = 8/10 with normal AFI.

A Manning score of 8 with normal AFV is managed by weekly NST monitoring.

Biophysical profile, aka Modified Manning score, is a screening test for uteroplacental insufficiency. The fetal CNS is highly sensitive to diminished oxygenation and helps plan the next course of action.

Hypoxia →metabolic acidosis → CNS depression → changes in fetal biophysical activity.

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria
Non-stress Test (NST)   ≥2 accelerations of 15 beats & a 15-second duration in a 20-minute period
Fetal breathing movements   ≥ 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting > 30 seconds
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone ≥ 1 episode of active extension(limb or trunk) with return of flexion.
Amniotic fluid volume A pocket of amniotic fluid that measures at least 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket)


Each parameter is given a score of 0 or 2 & a total of 10 is possible. 

BPP score Interpretation

Management
10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly
8 with normal AFV Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly
8 with decreased AFV Suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia If ≥36 weeks, delivery is done
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

If AFV is abnormal-Deliver>36 weeks
If AFV is normal- deliver≥ 37 weeks
4 Probable fetal asphyxia If ≥32 weeks, deliver
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Delivery

questions.text: 20. A 30-year-old female presents with fever with chills and abdominal pain 2 days after vaginal delivery. She also has foul-smelling lochia. Parametrial tenderness is elicited on abdominal and bimanual examination. Her WBC count was 25000/ microlitre. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Anaerobic streptococcus is the predominant pathogen involved
Risk is more with vaginal delivery when compared with Cesarean section
Placental site is involved most commonly following vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The risk of developing puerperal sepsis is more with a Cesarean section when compared with vaginal delivery.

* The most common route of spread of puerperal sepsis is direct spread

* The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in a cesarean section. (Option D)

* The most common manifestation of puerperal infection is Endometritis. (Option C)

* The most common cause of puerperal sepsis is Streptococcus. (Option A)

* The most important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis is the route of delivery (Cesarean > Vaginal). (Option B)

* The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following a cesarean section is administering a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery. None of the other steps with respect to surgical closure of the abdomen have proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection.

questions.text: 21. A 16-year-old boy presents with skin lesions over the dorsum of the hand as shown below. On examination, the lesions are firm papules with a rough horny surface. What is the most common causative agent of these lesions?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing multiple firm papules with a rough horny surface on the dorsum are suggestive of Verruca vulgaris or a common wart. The most common causative agent of common wart is the Human Papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2).

Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by HPV-2  but also by the closely related types 27, 57, and types 1 and 4. It is predominantly seen in adolescence and early adulthood and usually presents with firm papules with a rough horny surface.

 The most common sites in adults are the dorsum of the hand and fingers. However, in children, the common site is the knees. Lesions present on palmar aspects of the fingers may be tender when fissured or when growing beneath the nail plate. New lesions can appear at sites of trauma which are called Koebner-like isomorphic phenomena.



Other options:

HPV-3 and HPV-10 mainly cause plane (flat) warts or verruca plana. HPV 16 and 18 are associated with anogenital warts and cervical cancers. HPV 11 are the causative agent of anogenital warts, laryngeal papillomas, verrucous carcinoma.

questions.text: 22. A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to chest pain. He describes it as sharp and worsens on lying supine or breathing deeply. An EKG is obtained and shows PR depression and diffuse ST elevations. Which of the following is most likely to be found on cardiac examination?
questions.solution:
Considering the patient's symptoms and EKG findings, the most likely finding on cardiac examination is a triphasic rub. 

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

A pericardial rub is nearly 100% specific to pericarditis. This appears as a rough scratching sound at the end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. It is usually triphasic; ventricular systole, early diastolic filling, and late presystolic filling after atrial contraction. 

Types of pericarditis and their causes:

Serous pericarditis: It is seen in rheumatic fever, SLE, systemic scleroderma, tumors, uremia, viral infection, or tuberculosis. Mild inflammation of epicardial and pericardial surfaces. Exudative serous fluid which is usually only 50–200 mL thus, it develops slowly and rarely alters cardiac function.

Suppurative (purulent) pericarditis: Bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion Enter pericardial space by direct extension, seeding from blood, lymphatic spread, and seeding by instrumentation. Inflammation may extend into the surrounding mediastinum. Usually, this results in the organization and, therefore, constrictive pericarditis with clinical sequelae

Hemorrhagic pericarditis: Tuberculosis or malignant neoplasm (from lung or breast). This can also be seen following cardiac surgery

Caseous pericarditis: Almost always tubercular in origin

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar. There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

* Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment

* Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days

* Stage 3: T waves become inverted

* Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months. 

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

Option A: S3 can be physiological in young adults due to hyperdynamic circulation, but is almost always pathological in older adults. It occurs in states where this is high-output (anemia, thyrotoxicosis, pregnancy) or volume overload (LV failure). Pericarditis in and of itself does not have a hyperdynamic state.

Option C: A mid-systolic click would be seen in Mitral valve prolapse and is followed by a late systolic murmur.

Option D:  A (low-pitched) diastolic rumble is seen in mitral stenosis; usually preceded by an opening snap, which is heard soon after S2.

questions.text:
23. You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

choices.text: Can be used as an emergency contraceptive
Can be used in patients with mennorrhagia

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

* Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.

* Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

* Suspected pregnancy

* Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues

* Pelvic inflammatory disease (Option D) or lower genital tract infections

* Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea

* Anemia

* Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection

* Previous ectopic pregnancy 

* Scarred uterus

* Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years.



The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years. 

The following images represent the copper T 380A, multiload 375, and copper T 200.

questions.text: 24. A patient with hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes is advised to take colesevelam. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Binding of bile acid in the intestine

questions.solution:
Colesevelam is a bile acid–binding resin that binds bile acid in the intestine.

Colesevelam is the only bile acid sequestrant specifically approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes and is used as an adjunct to diet and exercise. It is also approved for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

questions.text: 25. An elderly lady presented with a history of trivial fall while climbing the stairs. She has pain in the right hip and is unable to walk. An X-ray was performed and is shown below. Which of the following is not a classification system for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of a fracture of the neck of femur. Gartland classification is used for supra-condylar fracture of the humerus.

Classifications of fracture neck of femur: 

* Garden classification: It is based on the degree of displacement of the fracture.



* Pauwels classification: It is based on the angle of inclination of the fracture with respect to the horizontal plane.



Anatomical classification

* Subcapital – a fracture just below the head;

* Transcervical – a fracture in the middle of the neck

* Basal – a fracture at the base of the neck

Fractured neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors). 

A plain radiograph may show the following features:

* Fracture in the neck of the femur

* Break in the medial cortex

* External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent

* Displacement of the greater trochanter

* Break in the trabecular stream

* Break in Shenton's line (as shown in the image below)

Clinical features of a fractured neck of femur include painful movements of the hip joint, shortening and external rotation of the affected limb, and tenderness in the hip. Active straight leg raising is not possible

Complications include non-union and avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

Pearl PM2202: Treatment of fracture neck of femur



Pearl PM2014: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

* Lateral condyle fracture humerus 

* Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella

* Fracture neck of femur

* Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 

* Monteggia fracture in adults

* Intra-articular fractures

questions.text: 26. A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features is referred from a PHC with the following chest X-ray. His dyspnea is worsening and his vitals are suddenly deteriorating. Which of the following clinical findings is unlikely to be seen in the patient?

choices.text: Hyper-resonance on percussion of the right thorax
Decreased chest movements on the left side
Absence or decreased breath sounds on the left thorax

questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. Hyper-resonance on percussion would be seen on the left thorax.



Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) it is called a tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

* Chest pain.

* Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.

* Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).

* Neck vein distention.

* Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.

* Decreased chest movements on the affected side.

* Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.

* Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax shows:  

* Thin, sharp white line that demarcates the visceral pleural edge.

* Absence of lung markings that are seen peripheral to this line.

* Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung. 

* Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen.

* Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

The below image is a plain chest x-ray AP view showing pneumothorax. A deep sulcus sign is seen (arrow):

questions.text: 27. A 31-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist performs laparoscopy, during which he finds the following lesions in the pelvis. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given condition is endometriosis. The laparoscopic picture shows powder-burn spots pathognomic of endometriosis. Estrogen therapy is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as it is the major risk factor for the condition.

Treatment of endometriosis:

1. Medical management:

For minimal disease, the drug of choice is NSAIDs. Oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow.

For moderate to severe diseases, oral progestogens are the first drugs to be started. They antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy. The drug of choice is GnRH agonist.

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

* G: GnRH analog

* O: Oral contraceptive pills

* L: Letrozole

* D: Danazol

* G: Gestrinone

* A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone 

* P: Progesterone

It is to be noted that mifepristone can help reduce pelvic pain and the extent of endometriosis, but its antiprogesterone effect can lead to endometrial changes due to prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure. The resulting endometrial changes range from endometrial hyperplasia to a new category described as progesteronereceptor-modulator-associated endometrial changes (PAECs). 

2. Surgical management:

Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy.

* Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.

* Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)

* Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

Risk factors for the development of endometriosis

* Family history

* Nulliparity

* Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen (early menarche, late menopause)

* Estrogen therapy

* In utero exposure to diethylstilbesterol (DES)

Key clinical features

* Dysmenorrhea

* Lower abdominal pain

* Infertility

* Pain during urination or defecation

* Constipation or diarrhea

* Irregular bleeding

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis has been a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Laparoscopy helps detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis, locate the site of endometriosis and staging, take a biopsy, and perform surgical ablation as a part of treatment.

Other investigations:

* CA-125 levels: raised in endometriosis.

* Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels: raised in the peritoneal fluid

* MRI

* Color Doppler

* Anti-endometrial antibodies



Pearl PM1005: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

* Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.

* Rectovaginal endometriosis.

* Ovarian endometriosis.

* Chocolate cyst of the ovary.

* Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.

* Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

* Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.

* Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.

* Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).

* Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.

* Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: 28. A 60 year old male with a history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction presents to the ophthalmology clinic with acute onset of severe eye pain and blurred vision. He is diagnosed with acute angle-closure glaucoma. The ophthalmologist is considering options to rapidly reduce intraocular pressure. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), because it can exacerbate fluid overload.

Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient, extracting water from intracellular compartments and expanding the extracellular fluid volume. In patients with heart failure, this sudden increase in plasma volume can overwhelm the compromised myocardium, leading to pulmonary edema and worsening heart failure.

Other options:

Option A: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humor production. It is contraindicated in patients with hepatic cirrhosis due to the risk of worsening hepatic encephalopathy, and in those with hyperchloremic acidosis or severe COPD because it can exacerbate metabolic or respiratory acidosis.

Option C: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2α analog that lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) by increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is safe to use in patients with heart failure. 

Option D: Brimonidine is an alpha-2 agonist that reduces aqueous humor production. It is safe in heart failure but causes respiratory depression in young children.

questions.text: 29. A patient with a history of using well water for cooking and consumption presents with vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, there is jaundice, hemoglobinuria, Mees lines on the nails, and features of hypovolemic shock. A toxicology screen is done, and the 24-hour urine sample is found to contain high amounts of a toxin. Which enzyme of Kreb's cycle will be inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (AKG) of the Krebs cycle is inhibited by this toxin, arsenite (inorganic arsenic salt).

α-Ketoglutarate is a rate-determining intermediate in the Krebs cycle. It has a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism as it acts as a precursor of glutamate and glutamine and promotes protein synthesis.

Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form succinyl-CoA and CO2 with the help of the multienzyme complex, AKG dehydrogenase. This enzyme complex requires the cofactors thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and coenzyme A. Arsenite inhibits this decarboxylation reaction and causes the substrate, α-ketoglutarate, to accumulate. 

Arsenic toxicity is either due to inhalation of toxic arsenic gas or chronic consumption of foods cooked in contaminated well water. It presents with malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. There may be hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, hypovolemic shock, and cardiovascular manifestations such as QT prolongation, polymorphous ventricular tachycardia, and congestive cardiomyopathy. Mees lines are a common dermatologic manifestation characterised by transverse white striae on the nail.

Arsenic toxicity is detected by measuring the 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic.



Other options: 

Option A: Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is inhibited by iodoacetate and arsenate. It is not a part of Krebs' cycle.

Arsenate inhibits both alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (a key enzyme in the Krebs cycle) and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (an enzyme involved in glycolysis). However, since the question specifically asks about an enzyme in the Krebs cycle, the correct answer is alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.

Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by fluoroacetate.

Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate.

Pearl PM0079: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme
Iodoacetate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Arsenate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Fluoride Enolase


 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme
Fluoroacetate Aconitase

Arsenite

 α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Malonate Succinate dehydrogenase


 

Inhibitors of electron transport

Complex Inhibitors
Complex I Piercidin, Amobarbital, Rotenone
Complex II TTFA, Carboxin, Malonate
Complex III BAL, Antimycin A
Complex IV Hydrogen sulphide, Carbon monoxide, Cyanide


 

Inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation

Agent Mechanism
Atractyloside Inhibits ADP and ATP Transporter
Oligomycin Blocks flow of protons through Fo complex


Pearl PM0091: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.




Pearl PM2099: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: 30. A sterilisation procedure is being performed on a 32-year old P2L2 woman. During the procedure, the mid-portion of the fallopian tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised. The proximal tubal stump is mobilized, buried and embedded into a pocket of myometrium. The distal tubal stump is buried between leaves of the broad ligament. Which of the following is the correct statement about this procedure?

choices.text: Cannot be done in conjunction with C section

questions.solution:
The procedure described is the Irving procedure which is a reliable method of sterilization. It involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

It is often done in conjunction with caesarian sections.

It is not a reversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision. Failure rates are less than 1 case in 1000 patients, making it a reliable method.



Uchida technique involves stripping the tubal serosa from the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, followed by ligation and excision of the stripped portion. The proximal stump is buried in the broad ligament while the distal stump is left open to the peritoneal cavity. This minimal tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty.



Other methods of sterilization include:

* Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

* Pomeroy's procedure: The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.

* Madlener's procedure: A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

* Kroener's technique: It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.

* Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.

* Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected between two clamps.

* Laparoscopic techniques: 

* Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.

* Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: 31. Which of the following is not true about irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)?

choices.text: Vague abdominal discomfort is a part of the diagnostic criteria
Diagnostic criteria should be fulfilled for at least 3 months to make the diagnosis
Painless diarrhea or constipation is not a part of the diagnostic criteria
Symptoms must be present at least once a week

questions.solution:
Vague abdominal discomfort is not a part of the diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Rome IV criteria have replaced abdominal discomfort with abdominal pain, and pain is now a prerequisite clinical feature of IBS. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterised by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria, which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation, or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS (Option C). The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected of having IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS.

The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil has been shown to be effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Pearl PM0774: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

* Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)

* Associated with a change in stool frequency

* Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Pearl PM2457: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

* Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine

* Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

* Opiate - Loperamide

* 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron

* Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

* Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol

* Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone

* Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide

* 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: 32. A first-year medical student is performing the following test on a given urine sample in the biochemistry lab. The urine sample is heated with BaSO4. The reagent, a solution of ferric chloride is added to the adsorbed precipitate. The positive test would indicate the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical test is Fouchet's test. It is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. 

In Fouchet's test, urine is heated with barium sulfate which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin which produces a green color.

Principle for all tests to detect bile pigments: Oxidizing agents readily oxidize bilirubin to biliverdin to form a green color.

Other tests for Bile pigments:

* Ehrlich's aldehyde reagent test - Bile pigments react with para dimethyl amino benzaldehyde to form a red color. 

* Gmelin's test -  Nitric acid is used as the oxidizing agent. 

* Schlesinger's test - Zinc ions are used as oxidizing agents.
