questions.text: 33. In the examination of an ulcer, which of the following is best assessed by palpation?
questions.solution:
The base of an ulcer is better felt than seen and hence should be assessed by palpation.

An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death. Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are: margin, edge, floor and base.



The margin is defined as the junction between the normal epithelium and the ulcer.

The edge is defined as the part between the margin and the floor. Five types of ulcer edges are commonly described as follows:



The floor is defined as the exposed surface of the ulcer. It is better seen than felt, and may contain granulation tissue, discharge or slough. Trophic ulcers have bone as the floor due to their depth.

The base is defined as the structure on which the ulcer rests, eg, bone or soft tissue. It is better felt than seen.

questions.text: 34. Following the cesarean delivery of a baby weighing 4.2 kg, the mother developed torrential vaginal bleeding. Examination revealed uterine atony, following which the obstetrician performed a suture as depicted in the image below. Identify the type of suture performed by the obstetrician.
questions.solution:
The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures also known as brace sutures and it is used in atonic PPH. 

B lynch suture is a technique to arrest haemorrhage in severe postpartum atony.

Observe the transverse highlighted region in the image showing a hysterotomy suture which is seen in a B- Lynch suture and absent in Hayman suture and Pereira suture.



The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are tied in a surgical knot, thus compressing the uterus anteroposteriorly. The success rate of this procedure is high with ischaemic uterine necrosis being a plausible complication.

Given below is a pictorial depiction of the various uterine compression sutures.

questions.text: 35. A patient presents to the dermatology clinic complaining that a birthmark that was asymptomatic has now become pruritic with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic naevus (birthmark), suggestive of halo dermatitis. 

It is also known as Meyerson nevus. Histology shows a benign naevus surrounded by a dermal lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrate, with acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis. The condition usually resolves spontaneously within few months without involution of the nevus.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic superficial scaly dermatitis is a chronic condition characterized by the presence of round or oval erythematous, slightly scaly patches on the limbs and trunk, as shown in the image below:



Option B: Nummular dermatitis appears as a well-demarcated coin-shaped erythematous plaque with vesicles surrounding it. Later central clearing (resolution) and peripheral extension lead to annular or ring-shaped lesions. Initially, it is red and pruritic but later, it becomes more scaly and less exudative. The image below shows nummular dermatitis:



Option C: Melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. The image below shows a malignant melanoma with asymmetrical shape and irregular borders:



Pearl PM0391: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:



A : Asymmetry

* Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

* Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

* The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

* Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

* There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: 36. Which of the following tests can be used to measure mucociliary function in vivo?
questions.solution:
Saccharine test can be used to measure mucociliary function in vivo. 

Various tests for mucociliary function:

* Saccharine Test: This simple and inexpensive test measures mucociliary transport rate by timing the patient's response to tasting saccharine particles placed on the nasal mucosa. It requires patient cooperation but provides a quick assessment of mucociliary function.

* Radioisotope Transport Testing: This test involves using radiolabeled particles in the nasal cavity, tracked with a γ-camera, to quantitatively assess mucociliary clearance. It's valuable for diagnosing conditions like primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and is not influenced by sniffing.

High-Speed Video Microscopy Analysis (HVMA): HVMA analyzes ciliary beat frequency and pattern using high-speed video microscopy, offering detailed insights into ciliary motion and coordination. The amplitude, degree, and speed of the ciliary beat cycle can also be measured. This is a laboratory technique; it is done in vitro and is not a direct measurement of mucociliary function. 

Other options: 

Option A: The nasal potential difference test is used to assess ion transport in nasal epithelial cells in patients with suspected cystic fibrosis.

Option C: Nasal Nitric Oxide (nNO)Testing: nNO testing measures nasal nitric oxide levels, lower in patients with primary ciliary dyskinesis, serving as a non-invasive screening tool, especially in older children. It cannot definitively diagnose or exclude PCD and may require further testing. 

Option D:  Studying epithelial biopsy samples under electron microscopy is an in vitro test of mucociliary function, not in vivo.

questions.text: 37. A 25-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of dyspnea on exertion. An ejection systolic murmur is heard in the 2nd intercostal space on auscultation. Further evaluation reveals that the left ventricular ejection fraction is 35%. The patient is planned for Ross procedure. Which of the following is used in the surgery to repair the valve?
questions.solution:
In the Ross procedure, a pulmonary autograft is taken and used for the replacement of the aortic valve.

The history of dyspnea on exertion, an ejection systolic murmur in the 2nd intercostal space, and a reduced ejection fraction point towards a diagnosis of aortic stenosis.

questions.text: 38. A 34-year-old pregnant woman who had previous recurrent abortions was found to have APLA (antiphospholipid antibody) syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, low-molecular-weight heparin (5000 units S/C twice daily) with low dose aspirin (50 mg daily) up to 34 weeks is the most efficacious regimen for APLA.

Aspirin in doses of 60-80mg blocks conversion of arachidonic acid to thromboxane A2 while sparing prostacyclin production. Heparin therapy prevents thrombosis in the microcirculation including decidual trophoblastic interface. 

Warfarin is not used due to its potential teratogenic effects.

The most common congenital defect due to warfarin in APLA mothers is craniofacial anomaly, and the most characteristic is chondrodysplasia punctata.

questions.text: 39. A 27-year-old woman presents with headache, fatigue, malar rash, and arthralgia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. Urinalysis revealed hematuria, proteinuria (4 g/dL), and RBC casts. She has high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies. A renal biopsy was done, and light microscopy showed sub-endothelial deposits, resembling wire-loop lesions. Findings of immunofluorescence staining are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Hemodialysis and maintenance therapy with azathioprine
Therapeutic plasma exchange and high-dose steroids
Low-dose steroids and azathioprine for 3-6 months
High-dose steroids and mycophenolate mofetil for 2-6 months

questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigation findings are diagnostic of lupus nephritis. The image shows a characteristic full-house pattern of positive staining for all immune reactants. The next best step in the management is to induce remission by administering high-dose steroids, in combination with mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide for 2-6 months. 

This is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine. (Option C)

Evaluating the clinical case given in the question:

* The presence of malar rash and arthralgia is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

* Urinalysis shows hematuria (>5 RBCs/HPF), and nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/dL), RBC casts. These findings, along with the presence of high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies, are indicative of lupus nephritis.

* Light microscopic examination of the renal biopsy revealed characteristic 'wire-loop' lesions, which are seen due to sub-endothelial immune complex deposition. The presence of wire-loop lesions is suggestive of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (class IV).

* Further, immunofluorescence staining, as shown in the image, revealed positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa, and lambda light chain), commonly known as the "full-house" effect, characteristic of lupus nephritis.



Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of SLE and is seen in about 30-50% of patients with the disease. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Depending on the biopsy findings, lupus nephritis is classified into six classes. 

Other options:

Option A: Haemodialysis is not the next step, but a few patients with lupus nephritis will reach end-stage disease and may require dialysis or transplantation. 

Option B: Therapeutic plasma exchange is not a conventional therapy used in lupus nephritis.

Pearl PM1568: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 


* Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli

* Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli

* Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus

* Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: 40. A 2-year-old male child is brought with pellagra-like symptoms and cutaneous photosensitivity. Elder sister has similar symptoms. Two other siblings are normal. The child most likely has__________

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra like symptoms, photosensitivity in a 2 year old child with autosomal inheritance is suggestive of Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease (pellagra like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan and other monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids (neutral amino acids). This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra like symptoms.

Clinical features:

* Most of the children are asymptomatic

* However, major clinical manifestation in the rare symptomatic patient is, cutaneous photosensitivity

* The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.

* Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

* Urine testing for amino acids.

* Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

* Niacin or niacinamide supplements

* Nicotinamide for attacks

Pearl PM0625: Amino acid Enzymatic Disorders and the Associated Enzymes

Disorder

Enzyme defect

Phenylketonuria

Phenylalanine hydroxylase

Tyrosinosis (Tyrosinemia type I)

Maleyl Acetate isomerase or Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Maple syrup urine disease 

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD)

Alkaptonuria

Homogentisate oxidase

Albinism

Tyrosinase

Homocystinuria type I

questions.text: 41. A histologist is studying the structure derived from the bone shown in the microscopic image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the canal marked by the square in the given image?

choices.text: Volkmann's canals communicate with each other by means of this canal
It is found in compact bone
It contains small blood vessels and nerves
It is surrounded by multiple lamellae of calcified matrix

questions.solution:
The given image shows the haversian canal, and the incorrect statement regarding the canal is that Volkmann's canals communicate with each other by means of this canal.

The haversian canals communicate with each other through the transverse perforating canals, called Volkmann's canals, and not vice versa.

The haversian system, or osteon, comprises most of the compact bone. Each haversian system contains a central canal, within which the small blood vessels, nerves, and endosteum are present. This canal is surrounded by multiple layers or lamellae of the calcified matrix containing type I collagen fibers. These canals communicate with each other via Volkmann's canal.

Successive lamellae are separated from each other by lacunae that contain osteocytes. These osteocytes communicate with each other, the central canal, and the periphery of the osteon via the dendritic processes present within the canaliculi. The parallel lamellae present between osteons is called interstitial lamellae, and the parallel lamellae present near the periosteum are called the circumferential lamellae.

On microscopy, the osteon can be identified by the following characteristics:

* Presence of the haversian canal with concentric lamellae around it

* Volkmann's canal

* Osteocytes with canaliculi

* Interstitial lamellae

* Circumferential lamellae

questions.text:
42. Which of the following clinical triads have fever as a component?

* Charcot's triad

* Saint's triad

* Murphy's triad

* Rigler's triad

questions.solution:
Charcot's triad of acute cholangitis and Murphy's triad of acute appendicitis have fever as components.

  • Small bowel obstruction
  • Pneumobilia
  • Ectopic gallstone

  • Melena
  • Biliary colic
  • Obstructive jaundice

questions.text: 43. A newborn on examination was found to have deafness, cataract and ventricular septal defect. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing this syndrome?

choices.text: Both postnatally and congenitally acquired infection can become carriers
The infected person can transmit infection from one week before the onset of rashes
It has one of the most effective vaccine available as seroconversion is more than 95%

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is classic for congenital rubella syndrome (deafness, cataract, and cardiac defects) and only congenitally acquired infection can turn into a carrier state.

There is no known carrier state for postnatally acquired rubella. However infants born with congenital rubella may shed the virus for many months.

Other options:

Option B: Single infection of rubella gives lifelong immunity. Once a person contracts rubella naturally or through vaccination, they are typically immune for life and do not get reinfected.

Option C: The infected person can transmit infection from one week before the onset of rashes to about one week after rash appears. 

Option D: It has one of the most effective vaccines available.The effectiveness of 1 dose of an RCV is > 95%, even at 9 months of age.

Pearl PM1450: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

* The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:

* Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome

* Congenital cataract

* Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus

* Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester

* Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness

* If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities

* Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.



 Rubella:

* Also called the German measles

* Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae

* Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash

* Droplet trasmission

* The incubation period is 2-3 weeks

* The rash appears on day 1

* Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx

* Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia

* The most serious complication is encephalitis

* Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: 44. Identify the incorrect statement about epidural anesthesia when compared to spinal anesthesia.

choices.text: The density of the block is less
Less chances of post-dural puncture headache
More useful in postoperative pain relief

questions.solution:
Epidural anesthesia has a slower onset of action when compared to spinal anesthesia. 

Epidural anesthesia is a method of neuraxial pain control in which anesthetic medications are injected into the epidural space to block sensory and motor spinal nerve roots in the thoracic, abdominal, pelvic, and lower extremity areas. It is widely used for surgical anesthesia, obstetric analgesia, postoperative pain control (option D), and chronic pain management.

In epidural anesthesia, the needle does not penetrate the dura mater; hence, the chances of a post-dural puncture headache are low (option C). However, compared to spinal anesthesia, it has a slower onset of action and a low density of the block (option B). 

The image below is of the 18G Tuohy needle, which is the most common needle used in epidural anesthesia. The needle shaft is calibrated and has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that prevents accidental dural puncture.



Pearl PM2276: Differences between Spinal and Epidural anesthesia

  Spinal (Subarachnoid, Intrathecal) anesthesia Epidural (Extradural) anesthesia
Level Below L1/L2, where the spinal cord ends At any level of the vertebral column (cervical to sacral)
Injection Subarachnoid space i.e. puncture of dura mater Epidural space i.e. without the puncture of dura mater
Identification CSF backflow Loss of resistance technique
Dose Low (2.5-3.5 ml of 0.5% hyperbaric Bupivacaine) High (15-20 ml of plain Bupivacaine 0.1-0.5% depending on the desired effect)
Dosing Single dosing With the catheter in situ, multiple dosing and continuous infusions possible
Onset of action Rapid (2-5 minutes) Slow (15-20 minutes)
Density of block More dense Less dense
Hypotension Rapid Slow
Complications (specific)

High spinal

Cardiac arrest

Post-dural puncture headache

Local anesthesia toxicity

Total spinal anesthesia

Epidural hematoma
Postoperative analgesia No Yes (with epidural infusion through the catheter)

questions.text: 45. A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. The histopathological image is given below. Identify the correct statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Associated with extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma in the thyroid gland
Characteristic Orphan Annie Eye nuclei seen
Neutrophilic infiltration seen in the thyroid

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is associated with extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma in the thyroid gland.

It is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well-demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

* Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres (Option D)

* Atrophied thyroid follicles 

* The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These cells are called Hurthle cells. They represent the metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury.



Clinical features include painless enlargement of the thyroid, which is generally symmetric and diffuse. Typically, hypothyroidism develops gradually. In some patients, however, it may be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis caused by disruption of thyroid follicles and release of thyroid hormones.

Individuals with Hashimoto's thyroiditis are at increased risk for the development of extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma within the thyroid gland. They are also at increased risk for developing other autoimmune diseases, both endocrine (type 1 diabetes, autoimmune adrenalitis) and non-endocrine (systemic lupus erythematosus, myasthenia gravis, and Sjögren syndrome).

Other options:

Option B and C: Characteristic Orphan Annie Eye nuclei and Psammoma bodies are seen in Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Some molecular studies suggest that Hashimoto's thyroiditis predisposes to papillary carcinoma.

Pearl PM0122: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)


* Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody

* Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody

* TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

questions.text: 46. Which of the following is not homologous to the structure marked X in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as X in the image is Gartner's cyst, and the appendix of the testis is not homologous to it in origin.

Gartner's cyst arises from the Gartner's duct—an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. Gartner's duct is located in the uterine broad ligament. In males, the mesonephric duct gives rise to the epididymis, seminal vesicles, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct.

The prostatic utricle and the appendix of the testis are remnants of the paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct in males.

questions.text: 47. A middle-aged woman with a BMI of 34 kg/m², visits her physician for weight loss. After being prescribed an anti-obesity medication, she experiences oily stools, abdominal cramps, and occasional fecal incontinence. Which medication is likely responsible for these side effects?
questions.solution:
Orlistat works by causing fat malabsorption, which can lead to gastrointestinal side effects such as abdominal cramps, oily stools and fecal incontinence. It inhibits gastric and pancreatic lipases, preventing the breakdown and absorption of dietary fats. 

Other options:

Option B: Sibutramine is a centrally acting appetite suppressant that was withdrawn from the market due to cardiovascular effects. 

Option C and D: Phentermine and Bupropion are associated with mild side effects like nausea and constipation, but severe GI side effects like steatorrhea is not seen.

questions.text: 48. An infant is brought to the paediatric OPD with lower respiratory tract symptom of expiratory wheeze. Bronchiolitis is suspected. A monoclonal antibody approved for prophylaxis of this condition acts against which glycoprotein?
questions.solution:
Nirsevimab and Palivizumab are monoclonal antibodies against the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), the most common cause of bronchiolitis. The monoclonal antibody targets F glycoprotein (fusion protein).

Palivizumab is a neutralizing humanized murine monoclonal antibody given intramuscularly once a month and has been approved for protecting high-risk children against serious complications from RSV disease. It is used to prevent lower respiratory tract disease in children at high risk of RSV infection. Palivizumab should be considered for infants younger than 2 years of age with chronic lung disease, a history of prematurity, and some forms of congenital heart disease. 

Nirsevimab is an RSV fusion-protein-specific monoclonal antibody. It is long-acting with an extended half-life because of engineered changes in the antibody Fc region. It is also indicated for the prevention of RSV lower respiratory tract disease in neonates and infants up to 19 months of age.

Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory wheezes, and breathing difficulty. In severe cases, cyanosis may be present. Some patients may have normal radiographs. However, the majority will have interstitial infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening.

Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment for infant bronchiolitis. IV immunoglobulins with high neutralizing potential against RSV can also be used for prophylaxis by reducing the replication and thereby decreasing the viral load. However, with the advent of humanized antiviral monoclonal antibodies, IVIGs are not frequently used now.

Note: The FDA has recently approved Clesrovimab, a monoclonal antibody, for the prevention of RSV in neonates and infants entering their first RSV season. It binds to a conserved epitope on the antigenic site IV on the RSV fusion (F) protein, inhibiting fusion of the viral membrane with the host cell membrane.

questions.text: 49. Ibrutinib is a _______
questions.solution:
Ibrutinib is a Bruton Tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

It inhibits malignant B-cell proliferation and is used in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia, small lymphocytic lymphoma, Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia and chronic graft-versus-host disease after failure of systemic therapy. It is also used in patients with mantle cell lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma who have received at least one prior therapy.

Other options:

Option B: Imatinib is a BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor.

Option C: Palbociclib is a CDK inhibitor approved for use in metastatic breast carcinoma.

Option D: Ruxolitinib is a Jak1/2 inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with polycythemia vera who have had an inadequate response to hydroxyurea and for the treatment of myelofibrosis.

questions.text: 50. During your labor postings, you notice the resident preferred the mediolateral episiotomy instead of the midline episiotomy. All of the following are true statements about mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy, except that _______.
questions.solution:
All of the following are true statements about the advantages of mediolateral episiotomy over a midline episiotomy except that blood loss is lesser (Option B). Mediolateral episiotomy is associated with a greater amount of blood loss than midline episiotomy.

Episiotomy: Surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor is called an episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy. 

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is the least Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension


Pearl PM0044: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

* Posterior vaginal wall

* Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani

* Fascia covering those muscles

* Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves

* Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: 51. A 10-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of recurrent seizures since childhood. EEG was normal, and MRI findings showed multiple subependymal nodules in the periventricular region. Which of the following drugs has been recently approved for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a history of recurrent seizures and the MRI finding of multiple subependymal nodules in the periventricular region is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis.

Everolimus acts on the mTOR; it has been recently approved for the treatment of patients with Subependymal Giant Cell Astrocytoma (SEGA) associated with TS. Everolimus is also used in used in kidney and liver transplant. 

The toxicity of Everolimus and the potential for drug interactions seem to be the same as with Sirolimus which includes anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, mouth ulcer, hypokalemia, and GI effects. 

Option B: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor and is highly effective in preventing graft rejection reactions. However, it is nephrotoxic.

Option C: Basiliximab is the interleukin-2 receptor antagonist. It is otherwise known as the anti-CD25 antibody. 

Option D: Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that blocks FKBP 12. This is an immunophilin that ultimately inhibits calcineurin phosphatase and exerts its actions.

questions.text: 52. A 45-year-old woman presented with a 5cm right lateral cervical neck mass below the angle of the jaw. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy revealed the atypical thyroid tissue and calcifications. Which of the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: It represents the part of thyroid that failed to fuse with the main gland
It represents the fibrous remnant of the thyroglossal duct
It represents a metastatic lymph node
It represents a form of thyroid agenesis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the lateral aberrant thyroid. It refers to metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes.

It may be the first presentation of a papillary microcarcinoma of the thyroid (lesions <10 mm, usually detected post thyroid resection). It was previously thought to be a portion of lateral anlage which failed to fuse with the main gland, as proposed by Crile. 

Normally the thyroglossal duct atrophies, although it may remain a fibrous band. In about 50% of individuals, the distal end that connects to the thyroid persists as a pyramidal lobe projecting up from the isthmus, lying just to the left or right of the midline. In normal individuals, the pyramidal lobe is not palpable, but in disorders resulting in thyroid hypertrophy (e.g., Graves’ disease, diffuse nodular goitre, or lymphocytic thyroiditis), the pyramidal lobe usually is enlarged and palpable.

Ectopic thyroid refers to the presence of thyroid tissue in abnormal locations. It is a form of thyroid agenesis.

questions.text: 53. Which of the following gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidneys?
questions.solution:
The division of the ureteric bud gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidney.

The kidney develops from 3 sources as follows:

* Metanephric blastema (Option C) gives rise to the excretory system of the kidney. It forms the Bowman's capsule, the proximal convoluted tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule. 

* The ureteric bud, an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct, gives rise to the kidney's collecting system. It forms the collecting ducts, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter.

* Angiogenic mesenchyme (Option A), which migrates into the metanephric blastema, gives rise to the glomeruli and the vasa recta. 

Option D: Primitive urogenital sinus arises from the ventral portion of the cloaca and gives rise to the vesicourethral canal cranially and definitive urogenital sinus caudally. The vesicourethral canal gives rise to the urinary bladder, female urethra, and prostatic part of the urethra in males. The definitive urogenital sinus gives rise to the membranous and penile urethra except for the terminal part in males.

questions.text: 54. What is the theme of World Heath day 2025?

choices.text: Immunization for all is humanly possible

questions.solution:
World Health Day is celebrated every year on April 7th. This year’s theme is "Healthy beginnings, hopeful futures".

Option B: My health, my right was the theme for World Health Day 2024

Option C: The theme for World Cancer Day from 2025-2027 is United by Unique. It is celebrated on Feb 4th.

Option D: Immunization for all is humanly possible is the theme for World Immunization Week 2025, celebrated every year from 24-30th April.

questions.text: 55. An elderly patient was brought to the emergency room with a severe headache. On examination, his blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg. CT scan of the brain showed bleeding in the globus pallidus. Which of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
Unilateral violent movement of large proximal joints
Semi purposeful, rapid jerky movements of proximal muscles and face
Rapid jerky contraction of groups of muscles

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of intracerebral bleed into globus pallidus secondary to hypertension. This results in damage to the globus pallidus resulting in athetosis, which is described as slow writhing movement involving distal joints.

The most common site of hypertensive bleed in the brain is basal ganglia and putamen. Patients typically present with severe headache. The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhages is hypertension.

Following are the usual locations of ICH: 

*   Basal ganglia hemorrhage (especially the putamen)

*   Thalamic hemorrhage

*   Pontine hemorrhage

*   Cerebellar hemorrhage 

The investigation of choice in stroke is non-contrast CT.

The following image shows bleeding in the basal ganglia on a non-contrast CT brain:

questions.text: 56. Which of the following is a sign of an artificial bruise?
questions.solution:
The presence of vesicles is a sign of an artificial bruise and is not seen in true bruises caused by trauma.

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances, such as the juice of marking nut, calotropis, or plumbago rosea, to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two categories.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible parts Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Rounded
Margins Well-defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles Present Absent
Redness/Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Chemical tests Positive Negative


Marking nut/Semecarpus anacardium:



Calotropis gigantea:

questions.text:
57. A 29-year-old woman presented with a mobile, painless mass in the lower, outer aspect of her right breast. It first appeared 4 months ago. A histopathological image of the mass is given below. Which of the following best describes the microscopic features?

BM - Basement membrane

choices.text: Bulbous protrusions extending into cystic space covered by epithelium
Delicate myxoid stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium
Clonal epithelial cell proliferation limited to ducts and lobules by the BM
Solid sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathology of the breast are most likely suggestive of fibroadenoma. Microscopy of fibroadenoma reveals delicate myxoid stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium.

Fibroadenomas are commonly occurring benign tumors of the breast. They generally occur in women who are in the 2nd or 3rd decade of life. In response to endogenous hormones, they may grow (pregnancy) or shrink in size (menopause). They may be multiple fibroadenomas and may occur bilaterally. 

Morphology: 

* Gross: They are well-circumscribed and rubbery with grey-white nodules that bulge above the surrounding tissue. 

* Microscopy: They have a delicate myxoid stroma resembling normal interlobular stroma with slit-like spaces lined by epithelium. Pericanalicular pattern shows epithelium surrounded by stroma, while the intracanalicular pattern has compressed epithelium.



Other options: 

Option A - Bulbous protrusions extending into cystic space covered by epithelium are seen in phyllodes tumor of the breast. The bulbous protrusions occur due to nodules of proliferating stroma. They also arise from the intralobular stroma but are not as common. They are generally present in the 6th decade. They have higher cellularity, higher mitotic figures, nuclear pleomorphism, stromal overgrowth, and infiltrative borders.



Option C - Clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the basement membrne is seen in ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). It can be detected by mammography and is curative with surgical excision and radiation. There are many subtypes of DCIS including but not limited to comedo, cribriform, micropapillary, papillary.



Option D - Solid sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli are sen in medullary carcinoma of the breast. It is a subtype of invasive breast cancer. Due to minimal desmoplasia, they are softer than the other carcinomas.

questions.text: 58. A 27-year-old woman with a BRCA1 mutation-positive and family history of Carcinoma of breast comes for screening. Which of the following investigations will be most suitable for this case?
questions.solution:
MRI is the most suitable investigation for BRCA1 mutation-positive patients.

BRCA1 mutation is associated with breast and ovarian cancer. MRI is the most sensitive investigation in patients with strong family history and BRCA1 positive. It is also useful since it's a young female with dense breasts.

Other Options:

Option A: USG breast is done in younger patients but since BRCA1 positive patients, MRI is the better investigation.

Option B: Mammography is preferred for screening of older patients > 40 years of age whereas USG is preferred in younger patients and patients with dense breasts.

Option D: Ductography is not used in screening.

questions.text: 59. A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (frequent sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (hemoptysis), and kidneys (hematuria), and an x-ray shows the presence of a cavity in the right lung. These, along with laboratory features and positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA (cANCA), suggest that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangitis (GPA).

GPA is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels. Also, necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis is present in the condition. Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, saddle nose, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present.

Antiproteinase 3-ANCA or antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (cANCA) is seen in 95% of patients and is a useful marker of disease activity.

Management is as follows:

* Induction with cyclophosphamide and glucocorticoids for severe disease. This is stopped after 3-6 months and can be switched to rituximab, azathioprine, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil for remission.

* Induction with rituximab and glucocorticoids is also effective in severe disease.

* For a non-severe disease, methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids is effective for induction as well as remission.

Other options:

Option A: In Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary-renal syndrome), anti-GBM autoantibodies are formed against the glomerular basement membrane. Younger patients present with hemoptysis, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria while older people present with isolated glomerulonephritis.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis mainly involves the small arterioles and venules. The presentation is similar to GPA. However, they do not have upper airway disease or pulmonary nodules. They have mainly MPO antibodies or P-ANCA positivity. The distinction can be made on a biopsy where microscopic polyangiitis would have vasculitis without granulomas. 

Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis that has palpable purpura over the buttocks and lower extremities, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children and the mechanism is immune complex deposition with IgA antibody.

Pearl PM0951: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining


Pearl PM0442: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: 60. A 12-year-old child was referred for a biopsy after his CT and MRI showed a space-occupying lesion in his cerebellum showing an enhancing nodule in post-contrast images. The tumour tested positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein and had the following histopathology image. What is the grade of this tumour as per the WHO classification?
questions.solution:
A space-occupying lesion showing an enhancing nodule, showing Rosenthal fibres on the HPE image, and testing positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is diagnostic of pilocytic astrocytoma. It is a WHO grade I glial tumour.

Option B: Grade II glial tumours are diffuse astrocytomas.

Option C: Grade III glial tumours are anaplastic astrocytomas.

Option D: Grade IV glial tumours are glioblastomas.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: 61. Cigar-shaped yeast in infected tissue is characteristic of _______.
questions.solution:
Cigar-shaped yeast is a feature of Sporotrichosis or rose gardener’s disease.

* It is caused by dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

* Most commonly follows minor trauma like thorn prick etc in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc.

* More common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Clinical features:

* Nodules along the lymphatics later undergo necrosis and ulceration.

* Spreads along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, supportive, and indurated.

* Other rare types – osteoarticular, pulmonary, disseminated type.

Diagnosis:

* Cigar-shaped yeast in H & E stained tissue sections.

* Culture – flower-like clusters of small conidia.

* Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell. It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherally by eosinophilic radiations

* Latex agglutination test

* Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin.

Treatment:

* Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide oral or topical

* Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole

* Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B



The image below reveals the conidiophores and conidia of the fungus Sporothrix schenckii during culture.



Asteroid bodies are shown below.



Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



 

Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



 

Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 62. A patient was administered a Hib PRP (polyribosyl ribitol phosphate) vaccine. The production of which of the following immunoglobulins is not induced by this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The Hib polyribosyl ribitol phosphate (PRP) vaccine does not induce IgE. 

IgG, IgA, and IgM are induced by the capsular PRP antigen of Hib. Although the production of IgE immunoglobulins may be induced, they do not play a significant role in the immune response generated by the vaccine. IgG, IgA, and IgM immunoglobulins are bactericidal, opsonic, and protective and hence, this antigen is employed for immunisation.

This capsular antigen is unique as it helps in capsular typing. This is of medical importance as up to 95% of H. influenzae isolates from acute invasive infections such as meningitis belong to type b. H. influenzae strains that lack a capsule are known as non-typeable strains. Non-typable H. influenza usually causes childhood otitis media, sinusitis, chronic bronchitis, puerperal sepsis, and exacerbations of COPD. Typeable H. influenzae causes meningitis.

H. influenza is typed into 6 serotypes (a to f) based on the capsular polysaccharide. H. influenzae b accounts for most of the invasive infections.

The differences between typable and non-typeable strains are given in the table:

Feature Type b strains Non-typable strains
Capsule Made up of Ribosyl-ribitol phosphate Unencapsulated
Pathogenesis Invasive infections due to hematogenous spread Local invasion along mucosal surfaces
Clinical manifestations
  • Meningitis and invasive infections in incompletely immunized infants and children
  • Epiglottitis
  • Cellulitis
  • Pneumonia
  • Otitis media in children
  • Exacerbation of COPD
  • Sinusitis
  • Puerperal sepsis
Vaccine Highly effective conjugate vaccines Not available

Pearl PM2056: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

* Half-life- 23 days

* Appears late, indicates chronic infection

* It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.

* Has 4 subclasses.

* Facilitates opsonization (via Fc receptor binding)

* Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and viruses.

IgM:

* Half-life- 5 days

* Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.

* Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.

* Intravascular distribution.

* Appears early, indicates recent infection.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

* Half-life- 2-8 days.

* Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.

* Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

* Half-life- 1-5 days

* Causes type I hypersensitivity.

* It is the only heat-labile antibody.

* Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

* Half-life- 6 days

* It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 

* Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: 63. Which of the following drugs can be cleared from the bloodstream via hemodialysis?
questions.solution:
Hemodialysis is useful in the removal of Valproate. 

The efficiency of hemodialysis in drug overdose or intoxication depends on molecular weight, water solubility, protein binding, endogenous clearance, and distribution of the drug in the body. 

A drug can be removed by hemodialysis if it has any of the following:

* Low molecular weight

* Low volume of distribution

* High solubility in water

* Minimal protein binding

Hemodialyzable drugs  Non-hemodialyzable drugs
Methanol Digoxin
Salicylate Diazepam
Valproate Verapamil
Phenobarbital Opioids
Lithium Metoprolol
Metformin Amphetamines


Generally, dialysis is indicated when medical management fails to control the following:

* Volume overload

* Hyperkalemia

* Acidosis

* Toxic ingestions

* Severe complications of uremia, like asterixis, pericardial rub or effusion, encephalopathy, and uremic bleeding

Other options:

Option A,B: Digoxin (6L/kg) and Propranolol (4L/kg) have a high volume of distribution and are largely sequestered in the tissues

Option D: Apixaban is highly protein-bound and cannot be extracted by hemodialysis.

Pearl PM2367: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

* Barbiturates

* Lithium

* Salicylates

* Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)

* Methanol

* Ethylene glycol

* Sodium valproate

* Isoniazid

* Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

* A- Amphetamines

* V- Verapamil

* O- Opiates, Organophosphorous

* I- Imipramine

* D- Digoxin

* Dialysis- Diazepam

Pearl PM2427: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis

Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: 64. A 35-year-old woman reported that she checks if the front door of her home is locked 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She mentions that this habit is not rational, but if she tries to prevent herself, she feels extremely anxious due to repetitive thoughts that the door is unlocked. Apart from checking her house front door, she also repeatedly checks to see if the gas stove is switched off. Which of the following is least suited for her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Electroconvulsive therapy is the least suited for the management of this condition.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comprises symptoms that include intrusive thoughts, ritu­als, preoccupations, and compulsions, which cause severe distress to the patient.

The recurrent and intrusive thoughts, feelings, ideas, and sensations are referred to as obsessions (doubt that the door is unlocked). Conscious, standardized, recurrent behaviors called compulsions (checking if the door is locked) are done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both.

Symptom patterns:

* Contamination - This is the most common symptom pattern of OCD where objects are perceived to be contaminated followed by either washing or a severe compulsion to avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or may refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.

* Pathological doubt - This is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession of doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door) which is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, if the stove is turned off.

* Intrusive thoughts - These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient doesn't agree with which might lead to the patient reporting themselves to the police/confess to a spiritual leader.

* Symmetry - The patients always need precision or symmetry in the work done and often this can lead to a compulsion of slowness. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

OCD is commonly associated with other common psychiatric comorbidities like depression, social phobia, alcohol use disorders, panic, and personality disorders.

Diagnosis of OCD is by the presence of:

* Obsessions, compulsions or both

* Time-consuming symptoms

* Symptoms not related to substance abuse

* Symptoms not better explained by other mental disorders

Treatment of OCD includes:

* Pharmacotherapy: SSRI or clomipramine

* Behavioral therapy: 

* Exposure and response prevention

* Desensitization

* Thought stopping

* Flooding

* Implosion therapy

* Aversive conditioning

A combination of behavioral and pharmacotherapy is found to be the most effective.

Pearl PM0552: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

* Most common:

* Obsession: Contamination

* Compulsion: Checking, cleaning

* Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.

* Drug of choice: High dose SSRI

* Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation

* Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

Pearl PM0498: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

* Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.

* Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

* Treatment-resistant depression

* Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)

* Depression with psychotic features

* Depressed suicidal pregnant women

* Refusal to eat or drink

* Imminent risk for suicide

* Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

* Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia

* Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

* Retrograde amnesia (most common)

* Partial anterograde amnesia

* Disorientation

* Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

* Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction

* Space occupying brain lesion

* Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: 65. A 20-year-old female patient presents with the finding shown in the image below. She is found to have Gilbert's syndrome. The discoloration of the sclera is attributed to the affinity of bilirubin towards ______.
questions.solution:
Scleral discolouration in patients with jaundice is due to the increased affinity of bilirubin to elastin. 

The high elastin concentration in sclerae results in a specific attraction to bilirubin, and the observation of scleral icterus suggests a minimum serum bilirubin level of 3 mg/dL. The identification of scleral icterus is much more challenging in the presence of fluorescent lighting within the examination room. If the examiner has reason to suspect the presence of scleral icterus, an additional area that should be assessed is the sublingual region. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

questions.text:
66. Trapeziectomy is done in which of the following deformities?

CMC joint- carpometacarpal joint FPL- Flexor pollicis longus

choices.text: Boutonnière deformity with CMC joint failure

questions.solution:
Trapeziectomy is done for Boutonnière deformity with CMC joint failure and for severe swan-neck deformity. It is a surgical procedure that involves excision of the trapezium. 

Other options:

* Arthritis mutilans – Arthrodesis with interposition bone graft is done.

* Game keepers thumb – Ligament reconstruction or MCP joint fusion

* Ruptured FPL –If painful: tendon graft or IP fusion.

questions.text:
67. ABG analysis of a patient reveals the findings given below. Which of the following is the most likely metabolic abnormality in this patient?

Blood pH: 7.50

PaCO2: 36 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Since both the pH and bicarbonate are increased it is a case of metabolic alkalosis. Also, in the case of metabolic alkalosis, respiratory compensation includes a rise in PaCO2. But in this case, it is less than expected, which suggests concomitant respiratory alkalosis.

Finding the primary abnormality

pH = 7.50 Normal = (7.35 – 7.45) Increased
paCO2 = 36 Normal = (35 – 45) Normal
HCO3- = 30 Normal = (22 – 28) Increased


These values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Calculating the compensation

In metabolic alkalosis, the predicted PaCO2 after compensation should be [HCO3-] + 15.

So PaCO2 level after compensation should be [30] + [15] = 45 mmHg. However, PaCO2 levels are 36 mmHg, which is far lower than the expected value. This indicates that there is a component of respiratory alkalosis in this patient as well.

Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: 68. Match the following for renal tubular disorders

choices.text: Bartter- F, Gordon- F, Fanconi syndrome- C, Liddle- C
Bartter- F, Gordon- C, Fanconi syndrome- C, Liddle- F
Bartter- C, Gordon- F, Fanconi syndrome- F, Liddle- C
Bartter- C, Gordon- C, Fanconi syndrome- F, Liddle- F

questions.solution:
The correct match is Option C. 

Liddle syndrome causes metabolic alkalosis [C]. It results from Increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC), which is characterized by hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypertension.

Bartter syndrome causes metabolic alkalosis [C]: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle. There is extracellular fluid volume depletion with low or normal blood pressure. It is characterized by metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and hypercalciuria.

Gordon syndrome causes metabolic acidosis (F): Gordon syndrome is pseudohypoaldosteronism type 2, characterized by metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and low renin and aldosterone levels.

Fanconi syndrome causes metabolic acidosis (F): A defect in the proximal tubule results in Fanconi's syndrome. These patients have acidosis, with glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.



Pearl PM2381: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: 69. Which of the following is true about the electrical state of the cardiac muscle during the T-P interval in an ECG, in a patient with myocardial infarction involving a portion of the left ventricle?

choices.text: The entire ventricle is depolarized, while the affected portion is repolarized
The entire ventricle is repolarized, while the affected portion is depolarized

questions.solution:
During the T-P interval in an ECG, in a patient with myocardial infarction, the entire ventricle is repolarized, while the affected portion of the cardiac muscle is depolarized.

T-P interval or T-P segment is the isoelectric interval on the ECG that Is present between the end of the T wave and the beginning of the next P wave. The T-P interval is used a reference to assess whether the ST segment is elevated or depressed.

In normal conditions, the entire ventricle gets depolarized by the end of the QRS complex, denoted by the J point. Between the J point and the beginning of the T wave (called ST-segment), the ventricle remains in the depolarized state.

Repolarization occurs during the T wave, and the ventricle then remains in the repolarized state during the T-P interval.

However, in patients with myocardial infarction, the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle does not undergo repolarization. Hence, the damaged portion will continue to remain in the depolarized state all through the T wave and the T-P interval.

Hence, in patients with myocardial infarction, during the T-P interval, the entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle, which remains in the depolarized state.

Pearl PM0203: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: 70. An 8-year-old boy presents with a headache for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning with associated nausea and vomiting. He was suspected to have meningitis. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Increase CSF production by the choroid plexus
Impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations
Impaired CSF drainage into the fourth ventricle
Impaired CSF drainage into the subarachnoid space

questions.solution:
This given scenario of an 8-year-old boy presenting with headache, nausea, and vomiting with meningitis and bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space on MRI suggests hydrocephalus due to impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations. 

CSF drains from the 4th ventricle into the subarachnoid space and the dural venous sinuses via arachnoid granulations. Due to this, CSF accumulates in the subarachnoid space and the ventricular space, as seen in communicating hydrocephalus or nonobstructive hydrocephalus, with subsequent symmetrical enlargement of the entire ventricular system and subarachnoid space.

Hydrocephalus can occur as an acute complication of bacterial meningitis because it is often caused by adhesive thickening of the arachnoid villi around the cisterns at the base of the brain. Thus, this thickening leads to interference with the normal resorption of CSF and the development of hydrocephalus.

Option A: Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus is seen in choroid plexus papilloma, which is a rare benign tumor that can manifest with features of increased ICP as well as enlargement of ventricles and subarachnoid space, but here, the history of fever and neck rigidity would not be seen, and the MRI would also show a well defined intraventricular lobulated mass.

Option C: Impaired CSF drainage in the 4th ventricle is seen due to obstruction of cerebral aqueduct / Aqueductal stenosis, which connects the 3rd and 4th ventricle, resulting in obstructive hydrocephalus. In obstructive hydrocephalus, there is only dilation of the ventricles above the obstruction and not subarachnoid space. 

Option D: Drainage of CSF into the subarachnoid space would be impaired upon blockage of the foramen of Magendie or foramen of Luschka, which connect the 4th ventricle with the subarachnoid space, resulting in obstructive hydrocephalus. In obstructive hydrocephalus, there is only dilation of the ventricles above the obstruction, not subarachnoid space.

questions.text: 71. As per the International Study Group (ISG) criteria for the diagnosis of Behçet’s disease, which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent genital ulcers,  associated with scarring
Presence of oral lichen planus-like lesions

questions.solution:
According to the International Study Group (ISG) criteria for the diagnosis of Behçet’s disease, the presence of oral lichen planus-like lesions is not a part of the diagnostic criteria.

International Study Group (ISG) criteria for the diagnosis of Behçet’s disease

Criteria Comments
Oral ulcers 3 times in a 12-month period
Plus 2 out of 4 from below  
Recurrent genital ulcers Usually scarring
Skin lesions

Erythema nodosum, pseudofolliculitis,

Papulopustular or acneiform nodules (postadolescent, not receiving corticosteroids)
Eye lesions Anterior/posterior uveitis cells in vitreous or retinal vasculitis
Pathergy 24–48 h, after dermal insertion of a 20-gauge needle


Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (pustular reaction 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection).

There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.

It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17 (Th17) cells play an important role in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall. The condition is treated with steroids, cyclophosphamide and TNF antagonists.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia B47

questions.text: 72. A 58-year-old man presents with insidious-onset dyspnea and occasional exertional chest pain. Further examination and investigations indicate a diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following drugs is most likely to improve this patient's dyspnea?
questions.solution:
The drug most likely to improve dyspnea in a patient with pulmonary hypertension is riociguat.

Riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator (sGC) and is indicated in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. It increases the sensitivity of nitric oxide to sGC and also directly stimulates the sGC enzyme resulting in increased formation of cGMP. This leads to relaxation in the pulmonary vasculature.

Another class of drugs used in PAH is phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors. These drugs prevent the breakdown of cGMP by phosphodiesterase, thus keeping the vessels in a dilated state. This class of drugs includes sildenafil and tadalafil. Headache and flushing are the most commonly reported side effects.



Other Options:

Option A: Rimonabant is an inverse agonist at cannabinoid receptor CB1 which decreases neurotransmitter release at GABAergic and glutamatergic synapses; its usage for smoking cessation and treatment of obesity was stopped after serious side effects notably severe depression and increased risk of suicide.

Option C: Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor approved for use in COPD. 

Option D: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitors that inhibit the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

Pearl PM1209: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

Drug Class Examples
Prostacyclin derivative

Epoprostenol

Iloprost

Treprostinil
Endothelin receptor antagonist

Bosentan

Ambrisentan

Macitentan
PDE5 inhibitor

Sildenafil

Tadalafil
Soluble guanyl cyclase stimulator Riociguat
Calcium channel blocker

Nifedipine

Diltiazem

Amlodipine

questions.text: 73. What is the nerve supply of the muscle shown acting in the given graphic ?
questions.solution:
The muscle acting in the given graphic is the platysma, which is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve.

The platysma is a broad sheet of muscle in the anterior aspect of the neck. It arises from the fascia covering the upper parts of the pectoralis major and deltoid. Its fibres cross the clavicle and ascend medially in the side of the neck. Interlacing of the anterior fibres from the contralateral muscle occurs in the midline, below and behind the symphysis menti. The fibres attach to the symphysis menti, the lower border of the mandible, the lower lip, or cross the mandible to attach to skin and subcutaneous tissue of the lower face.

The submental branch of the facial artery and the suprascapular artery supply the platysma. The suprascapular artery is derived from the thyrocervical trunk of the subclavian artery. It is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve. This branch descends close to the angle of the mandible, on the deep surface of the muscle and supplies it.

Contraction of the platysma produces tense, oblique ridges in the skin of the neck. This reduces the concavity between the jaw and the side of the neck. Platysma may assist in depressing the mandible. Due to its labial and modiolar attachments, it can draw down the lower lip and corners of the mouth in expressions of horror or surprise. During neck dissection in the subplatysmal plane, there should be careful elevation of a myocutaneous flap with the platysma and its blood supply. This reduces the risk of skin necrosis and improves wound healing.

Other options:

Option A: The ansa cervicalis is a part of the cervical plexus. It supplies the infrahyoid muscles (sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid), except the thyrohyoid, which is supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve.

Option B: The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.

Option D: The first cervical spinal nerve branches off from the hypoglossal nerve and supplies the thyrohyoid muscle.
