questions.text: 93. A woman came to the hospital for a regular physical check-up. She was classified to have class I obesity. What is her probable range of body mass index (BMI) as per the WHO classification for the global population?
questions.solution:
The range of BMI for class I obesity as per the WHO classification for the global population is 30.00-34.99.

People categorized as class I, class II, and class III obesity have moderate, severe, and very severe risk of comorbidities respectively.

Body mass index (BMI) is a statistical index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight, and obese in adults. It is defined as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters (kg/m2).

Class I obesity is described when a person has a BMI of:

* 30.0-34.99 in global population, or

* 25- 29.9 in Indian population

These BMI values are age-independent and remain the same for both sexes.

The risks that are related to raising BMI are continuous and graded. They begin at a BMI above 25. BMI fails to distinguish between muscle weight and weight due to fat. The percentage of body fat mass increases in both genders till the age of 60-65 years. It is higher in women as compared to men with equivalent BMI.

Pearl PM2065: Body mass index

Recent update for Asian population:

Classification Global population (kg/m2)  

Indian population

(kg/m2)
Underweight <18.5

<18.5
Normal  18.5-24.99 18.5-22.99
Overweight 25-29.99 23-24.99 (and At risk)
Obesity >30 >25
Class I obesity 30.0-34.99  25- 29.9
Class II Obesity 35.0 to 39.99  >30
Class III Obesity (severe, extreme, massive) ≥40  


Note:

Lethal BMI:

BMI Value of 13 is considered as “Lethal” in men.

Females withstand and survive even at lower BMI rate upto 11.

questions.text: 94. A 38-year-old lady visits your clinic with blood in her urine and intermittent urinary urgency and frequency. She has multiple sclerosis and had a catheter changed last month. Urinalysis indicates 3-5 RBCs per HPF without pus cells. The appearance of a lesion on flexible cystoscopy is as shown below. No metaplasia was found in the lesion biopsies and immunostaining. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from irritation of the bladder mucosa, most commonly due to indwelling catheters. The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections due to marked submucosal edema. They must be differentiated from papillary urothelial carcinoma.

The given image below shows polypoid cystitis showing broad polypoid growth, prominent blood vessels, and metaplastic urothelium in H&E stain.



Other options:

Option A: Interstitial cystitis, also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome, is a disorder of the urinary bladder that presents with urinary tract symptoms of more than six weeks duration of unknown etiology. Grossly, it is associated with chronic mucosal ulcers called Hunner's ulcers. Microscopically, there is a non-specific increase in mast cells in the submucosa. Biopsy should be done in all cases to rule out carcinoma in situ.

The cystoscopy image shows Hunner's ulcer, seen in interstitial cystitis.



Option C: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It is caused due to acquired defects in phagocyte function, chronic bacterial infection by Escherichia coli or Proteus species, and immunosuppression (renal transplant patients). Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages in malakoplakia have abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products and intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions. These are known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia (shown below).



Option D: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumours. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions.

Pearl PM2286: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: 95. The histopathological study of a cancerous ulcerative skin lesion is shown below. What kind of an ulcer edge is this pathology likely to have on gross examination?
questions.solution:
The above image shows atypical tumor cells and keratin pearls, which are indicative of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). It commonly presents with an everted edge.

SCC is the second most common skin cancer. The primary risk factor and driving force for the development of this common cancer is UV exposure (ex, gardener), previous chronic wounds, or chemical carcinogens.

Variants : 

* Bowen's disease

* Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. All these lesions later ulcerate and have a characteristic everted edge and are surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Keratin pearls are seen on histopathologic examination:



Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities include cautery ablation, cryotherapy, drug therapy, including imiquimod, and radiation therapy.

questions.text: 96. A patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. The given trophozoite stage is found in the stool sample. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the trophozoite stage of Balantidium coli.

It is the only ciliated pathogenic protozoan infecting humans and is present in the large intestine as a commensal. It is the largest protozoan parasite of humans.

Trophozoite:

* Large ovoid cell enclosed within a delicate pellicle showing longitudinal striations.

* Has a narrow anterior end and a broad posterior end.

* The cell has 2 nuclei—a large, kidney-shaped macronucleus and a small micronucleus lying in its concavity.

* 1 or 2 contractile vacuoles and several food vacuoles are present in the cytoplasm

* There is a groove (peristome) at the anterior end that leads to the mouth (cytostome), and a short funnel-shaped gullet (cytopharynx).

* A small anal pore (cytopyge) is present posteriorly.

* The cilia around the mouth are larger (adoral cilia)

* Lives in the large intestine and feeds on cell debris, bacteria, starch grains, and other particles.

* The trophozoite is actively motile due to the presence of short, delicate cilia over the entire surface of the body. The invasive stage of the parasite is found in dysenteric stool.

Cyst:

* It is spherical and measures 40–60 μm in diameter

* A thick and transparent double-layered wall surrounds it

* The cytoplasm is granular and has the macronucleus, micronucleus, and vacuoles present.

* The cyst is the infective stage of B. coli and is found in chronic cases and carriers.

Balantidiasis is a zoonosis that is mostly asymptomatic. Pigs are the definitive hosts, and man is an accidental host. Symptomatic disease presents with diarrhea or dysentery. The presence of intestinal ulcers and submucosal abscesses resembles amoebiasis.

The following image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli.

questions.text:
97. Match the given amniotic fluid findings with their respective causative condition.

Color of amniotic fluid Conditions
1. Dark red a. Rh-incompatibility
2. Green

b. Fetal distress
3. Golden-yellow c. Post-maturity
4. Saffron d. Abruptio placenta
  e. Intrauterine fetal demise
questions.solution:
Abnormal color of the Amniotic fluid and their causes are as follows

Color of amniotic fluid Conditions
1. Dark red d. Abruptio placenta
2. Green

b. Fetal distress
3. Golden-yellow a. Rh-incompatibility 
4. Saffron c. Post-maturity 
   


  Amniotic fluid in early pregnancy is colorless, but near term it becomes pale straw-colored due to the presence of exfoliated lanugo and epidermal cells from the fetal skin. Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to the hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Meconium stained (green) amniotic fluid is suggestive of fetal distress.

In a post-term (> 42 weeks) pregnancy, the amniotic fluid is found to be Saffron in color.

In intrauterine death ( absent fetal movements and FHS absent on doppler), a tobacco juice-colored amniotic fluid is seen. The dark color is due to the frequent presence of old HbA.

Dark red/maroon colored amniotic fluid is seen in concealed accidental hemorrhage as in cases of abruptio placenta.

Pearl PM1397: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: 98. A researcher wanted to study the social background of the disease under his study. He had a set of predetermined questions to interview his study population. What is the type of interview?
questions.solution:
The type of interview, in this case, is a structured interview where a set of predetermined questions are prepared and the reviewer gets the answers to those questions. 

Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. The technique is helpful in understanding the social and psychological factors in the natural history of the disease.

Types of interviews are: 

* Direct or structured interview - consists of a set of predetermined questions

* Non-directive or unstructured interview - doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions

* Focused interview - is usually used to study the effects of mass communications like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect of the problem and draws responses from people

* Repetitive interview - is used to find the gradual influence of social or psychological processes along with the maintenance of records

Pearl PM0850: The Art of Intervieweing

* Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. A proper interview technique must be employed to achieve the objective.

* Aims of an interview

* To secure information usually through face to face association and to understand the individual/group being interviewed.

* To form a hypothesis.

* To collect personal data for quantitative purposes.

* To collect data from secondary sources of information.

* Types of interviews

* A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence.

* A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions.

* A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communications like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem and draws responses from people.

* A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

* Technique of interviewing

* Establishing contact

* Starting an interview

* Securing rapport

* Recall

* Probe questions

* Encouragement

* Guiding the interview

* Recording

* Closing the interview

* Report

questions.text:
99. A 55-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen for the last 20 years due to back pain. The following findings are seen in his peripheral smear. Which of the following is likely to be been seen in this patient?

TIBC - Total iron-binding capacity

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of iron-deficiency anaemia (IDA). In iron-deficiency anaemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, as seen in this patient, where it presents as anaemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron-deficiency anaemia.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and chronic blood loss. The cause of IDA in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth), and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

The image given below shows koilonychia:



Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low haemoglobin level and low hematocrit. Serum levels of iron and ferritin are low, while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis and, hence, hepcidin is low.

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

* Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor

* Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and target cells

The image below shows a peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells:



Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate rise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stains in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral, and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anaemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

* Up to 200 mg of elemental iron is given.

* According to the Anaemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg of elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight (kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's haemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000 mg (for stores).

Pearl PM2146: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease Sideroblastic Anemia
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased Increased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased Increased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased Decreased


TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: 100. A 30-year-old male patient presented with painful genital ulcers for the past two weeks. Examination revealed multiple, bleeding, soft ulcers that are exquisitely tender and bleed easily. The inguinal lymph nodes are tender and fluctuant. Which of the following would be a suitable culture medium for the suspected organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Among the given options, chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the most suitable culture media for isolating the organism. 

H. ducreyi are gram-negative bacilli. On staining, they are sometimes seen arranged in a characteristic 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance. 

Clinically, patients develop an H. ducreyi infection from sexual contact with an infected person. Following this, they develop a papule that progresses to a pustule and finally a circumscribed ulcer. This is called chancroid or 'soft sore' and it may be single or multiple, very painful, bleeds easily, and is non-indurated. The infection then spreads to the lymph nodes which become tender, inflamed, and then suppurated. 

Diagnosis is established by isolating the organism on culture. The specimen may include scrapings from the ulcer base and aspirate from the suppurated lymph node. Culture is difficult but they can be grown on chocolate agar enriched with IsoVitaleX and vancomycin, fresh clotted rabbit blood, or on the chorioallantoic membrane of the chick embryo. H. ducreyi requires media enriched with the X factor, but not the V factor for growth. 

Treatment is with a single oral dose of 1g of azithromycin. Other options include oral ciprofloxacin, IM ceftriaxone, and oral erythromycin. Sexual contacts of these patients must be treated regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. 

Other options-

Option A - Thayer Martin medium is used for the isolation of Neisseria species. Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and meningococcemia presenting as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. Neisseria gonorrhea causes urethritis, proctitis, vulvovaginitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection. 

Option B - Tellurite blood agar is used for the isolation of Corynebacterium species. Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria with variable presentation. It can lead to asphyxia, circulatory failure, toxemia and local necrotic changes. 

Option D - Ashdown's medium is used for the isolation of Burkholderia pseudomallei species. This bacteria causes melioidosis. It may be acute presenting as acute septicemia and typhoid or pneumonia-like disease. In the chronic form, it presents with multiple caseous or suppurative foci.

Pearl PM0008: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 7-84 days 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline/Azithromycin

questions.text: 101. A technetium-99 m scan of a 3-year-old boy with Meckel's diverticulum is given below. Identify the false statement regarding this imaging modality in the given condition.

choices.text: Detects the presence of ectopic gastric tissue
Less sensitive for diagnosis in adults
CT is the most accurate investigation for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding imaging modalities in Meckel's diverticulum is- CT is the most accurate for diagnosis in Meckel's diverticulum. Sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticula in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but may present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Diagnosis of Meckel’s diverticulum:

In the absence of bleeding, Meckel’s diverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention. Plain abdominal X-ray, CT, and ultrasonography are rarely helpful in the diagnosis. 

Radionuclide scans like the 99mTc-pertechnetate accurately detect the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa. In children who present with bleeding, ectopic gastric mucosa is found in the majority of the cases. Hence, the most accurate diagnostic test in children. It is less accurate in adults. 

The sensitivity of the scan can be improved by H2-receptor antagonists like cimetidine. It leads to a higher concentration of radionucleotide in the wall of the diverticulum.

Angiography may be used to locate the site of bleeding in acute hemorrhage. The presence of a persistent vitelline artery is diagnostic.

questions.text: 102. False statement about nausea and vomiting associated with neuraxial blockade is

choices.text: Hyopotension following spinal anesthesia is a cause
Adding epinephrine to local anesthetic predisposes
Atropine may be effective in treatment
Among intrathecal opioids, morphine has the least incidence of nausea and vomiting

questions.solution:
Among the opioids commonly added to intrathecal or epidural local anesthetics, morphine administration has the most risk of nausea and vomiting whereas fentanyl  and sufentanil carry the least frequent risk.

Possible mechanisms that contribute to nausea and vomiting in the setting of neuraxial anesthesia: 

* Direct exposure of the chemoreceptive trigger zone in the brain to emetogenic drugs (e.g., opioids)

* Hypotension associated with generalized vasodilation

* Gastrointestinal hyperperistalsis secondary to unopposed parasympathetic activity

Factors associated with developing nausea or vomiting after spinal anesthesia include:

* Addition of phenylephrine or epinephrine to local anesthetics

* Peak block height greater than or equal to T5

* Baseline heart rate greater than 60 beats/min

* Use of procaine

* History of motion sickness

Atropine is effective in treating nausea associated with high (T5) subarachnoid anesthesia.

questions.text: 103. A woman was diagnosed with Stage 3 gestational trophoblastic neoplasia as per the classification by the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO). Which of the following images represents her stage?
questions.solution:
According to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to lungs are considered stage III gestational trophoblastic neoplasia(GTN), represented by image 3.

FIGO Stage  Extent
Stage I   GTN confined to the uterus

Stage II 

 GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures (adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III  GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV  All other metastatic sites


 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

* Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer

* Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer

* Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more

* Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text: 104. A 25-year-old male presents with a several-year history of a red hyperkeratotic papular eruption on the scalp, face, and chest. Examination of the nails reveals red and white longitudinal streaks and distal nicks in the nail plate. Which of the following would be an appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Darier disease, also known as Keratosis follicularis. Topical retinoids like Adapalene is an effective drug for this condition.

In Darier Disease, ATP2A2, a gene that encodes for Ca2+ ATPase type 2 of sarcoplasmic reticulum(SERCA 2) is mutated. It is essential for desmosome function. The dysfunction of desmosomes leads to loss of keratinocyte adhesion to each other, and this causes keratinocyte separation (Acantholysis) and blistering in the suprabasal epidermis. 

Clinical features:

* Discrete or confluent rough, greasy, skin-colored papules in seborrheic areas (trunk, face scalp margins) and the flexures (perineum, axillae, groin).

* Isolated nipple hyperkeratosis.

* Plane wart-like lesions, acrokeratosis verruciformis on dorsal hands.

* Nail fragility, painful longitudinal splits, or distinctive red and white longitudinal bands terminating in V-shaped nicks are typical.

* Oral, esophageal, cervical, or rectal mucosal involvement with white umbilicate or cobblestone papules are seen. 

* Ocular manifestations include hyperkeratotic plaques and seborrheic debris at the eyelid margin. Chronic blepharitis and corneal erosions and endophthalmitis have also been reported.

Symptoms can be managed by wearing loose clothing and avoiding sweating. Sun protection must be stressed. Secondary infection by bacteria, Herpes simplex virus, and candida is common.

Treatment options include:

First Line
  • Emollients and topical antiseptics
  • Avoid excess heat or UVB
Second Line
  • Topical combination corticosteroids with antifungals/antibiotics
  • Topical retinoids
  • Oral antivirals, e.g. Acyclovir
Third Line
  • Topical 5‐ fluorouracil cream,
  • topical tacrolimus, topical tacalcitol,
  • Oral alitretinoin, Photodynamic therapy


Pseudo-Darier's sign is the temporarily increased induration or piloerection on firm stroking of a lesion, seen in smooth muscle hamartoma.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. It is seen in cutaneous mastocytosis, most common among them is urticaria pigmentosa. In rare cases, it may be seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

questions.text: 105. A 60-year-old woman enjoys taking long walks in the park with her peer group. However, over the past few months, she has been unable to keep pace with her friends and feels breathless during these walks. According to the Modified Medical Research Council scale, which grade does she belong to?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario described, the woman is classified as Grade 2 on the mMRC dyspnea scale.

The Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale is used to classify the severity of symptoms in respiratory diseases, specifically COPD.

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

* Grade 0 -Not troubled by breathlessness, except with strenuous exercise 

* Grade 1 - Shortness of breath walking on level ground or walking up a slight hill

* Grade 2 - Walks slower than people of similar age on level ground due to breathlessness, or has to stop to rest when walking at their own pace on level ground.

* Grade 3 - Stops to rest after walking about 100 yards(~91m) or after walking a few minutes on level ground

* Grade 4 - Too breathless to leave the house, or breathless with activities of daily living (e.g., dressing/ undressing)

questions.text: 106. Which is the last region to show changes in rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Fingers and toes are the last to show changes in rigor mortis.

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in that order. It disappears in the same order of appearance. The rigor mortis changes begin in the heart. 

The order of appearance of rigor mortis:

* Involuntary muscles: Heart

* Eyelids

* Neck and lower jaw

* Face

* Chest

* Upper extremities

* Abdomen

* Legs

* Fingers and toes

questions.text: 107. A male infant with recurrent infections and an absent thymic shadow is suspected of having an X-linked variant of Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) disorder. The most likely defect seen in this child is

choices.text: Mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors

questions.solution:
The most common form of SCID is X-linked, which results from a Mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. 

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is an immunodeficiency state characterized by defects in humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Its sufferers are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and many other bacterial species. Based on the pattern of inheritance, there are two types of SCID.

X-linked SCID is the most common form. It is caused by a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. On biopsy, the thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus. These transmembrane proteins form integral parts of Interleukin receptors, especially IL-7 and IL-15, which are involved in the development of T-cells and NK-cells, respectively. Defects in the receptor signal transmission from these Interleukins will result in a fall in T-cell and NK-cell numbers due to defects in the early stages of their development. B-cells, although not reduced in number, cannot produce antibodies normally as T-cells are depleted in number.

Currently, HSC (Hematopoietic Stem Cell) transplantation is the mainstay of treatment in SCID, but X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful. 

Other options: 

Option A: Deficiency of HGPRTase results in Lesh Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by intellectual disability, self-mutilation, aggression, hyperuricemia, and gout.

Option B: Deficiency of NADPH oxidase is seen in Chronic granulomatous disease, which predisposes individuals to catalase-positive microbial infections.

Option C: Deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA) is seen in Autosomal recessive SCID. It leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes. On biopsy of the thymus, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

questions.text: 108. Which of the following is true regarding the drug delivery system shown in the image below?

choices.text: Ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug till patch is applied
Drug absorption versus time graph has more peaks compared to an oral drug
Ensures hundred percent bioavailability of the drug
Absorption is independent of the surface area over which it is applied

questions.solution:
The image shows a transdermal patch for transdermal drug delivery. It ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug.

Transdermal patches like these are available for 

* Nicotine for smoking cessation

* Oestradiol for HRT

* GTN for angina

* Fentanyl for analgesia

The absorption of drugs through intact skin is dependent on the surface area over which they are applied and their lipid solubility. The site of the application of the transdermal patches may affect the systemic drug concentration, as absorption through dermal circulation is a bit different over different areas of skin. For example, absorption from nicotine patches applied over the upper arm and back was higher compared to when it was applied to the abdomen.

The diagram below explains the parts of a transdermal patch.



Other options:

Option B: The drug absorption versus time graph has fewer peaks compared to an oral drug and, therefore, fewer toxicities.

Option C: A hundred percent bioavailability is possible only with intravenous administration

Option D: The absorption of the drug is dependent on the surface area on which the transdermal patch is applied and the lipid solubility of the drug.

questions.text: 109. Identify the false statement about the instrument given below.

choices.text: Palmer's point is the preferred entry site in high-risk patients.
Potential for bowel injury is lesser in the technique using this instrument.
Used for creating pneumoperitoneum by closed method.
Preferred in patients with previous abdominal surgeries.

questions.solution:
The image is that of a Hasson trocar which is used in the open method of creating pneumoperitoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

* Closed method

* Open method

The open method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound. The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar is inserted and anchored, and a pneumoperitoneum is created.

The safest site of entry in high-risk patients is the left upper quadrant, better known as Palmer's point. This site is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the midclavicular line. It is rarely affected by adhesions.

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The image below shows a Veress needle.

questions.text: 110. A 20-year-old man presents with a soft tissue tumour of the lower leg. The tumour closely approximates the knee joint but does not appear to arise within or communicate with the synovium. Microscopy reveals a spindled-cell proliferation with admixed epithelial components, and molecular testing shows an X;18 translocation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing a spindled-cell proliferation with admixed epithelial components, and molecular testing showing an X;18 translocation, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be Synovial sarcoma.

Synovial sarcoma is a misnomer as the soft tissue malignancy does not appear to be related to the synovium. It can be present in locations that lack synovium, and its morphologic features are inconsistent with an origin from synoviocytes. It occurs in people between the 2nd to 4th decades. Patients often present with a deep-seated mass that has been present for several years. 

It is commonly biphasic with both spindled and epithelial components demonstrable on both light microscopy and immunohistochemistry. Monophasic sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with little cytoplasm but dense chromatin in tightly packed fascicles.

A chromosomal translocation t(x;18) (p11;q11) that produces fusion of the SS18 gene to one of three SSX genes is present in most synovial sarcomas. Immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing these tumours as the epithelial antigens (keratins) differentiate synovial sarcomas from other sarcomas. 

Other Options:

Option B: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma shows sheets of pleomorphic spindle cells with high mitotic activity, suggesting a high-grade malignant tumor.

Option C: Liposarcoma is a malignant fat tissue tumor, usually occurring in adults, and would stain positive for S100.

Option D: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. Rhabdomyosarcomas show t(1;13) or t(2;13), are aggressive tumors and require surgical resection and chemotherapy.

questions.text: 111. In which of the following scenarios would you use the instrument shown in the given image?

choices.text: Fetus at 31 weeks gestation with respiratory distress
Baby with estimated weight of 4.3 kg in cephalic presentation
Term fetus with face as the presenting part
Term baby with maternal mitral valve prolapse

questions.solution:
The given image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery system. Among the given options, a term fetus with maternal mitral valve prolapse would be delivered using this system in order to minimize maternal exhaustion and to cut short the second stage of labor.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

* Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)

* Preterm fetus (less than 32 weeks)

* Suspected fetal coagulation disorder

* Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. 

The instrument consists of 

* Suction cup,

* Vacuum generator, and

* Traction tubing device.

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about 6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.



Once the cup is placed over the flexion point, the ventouse extraction begins by slowly initiating a vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute until the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm2 and then traction is applied.

The traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous with the uterine contractions. In between the uterine contractions, the traction is released. The traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if there is no descent of the presenting part with each pull and delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed beyond 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve, and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Pearl PM0042: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

* Fetal distress in second stage

* Maternal distress in second stage

* Prolonged second stage

* Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior

* High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

* Preeclampsia

* VBAC

* Cardiac defects

* Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

* Preterm head

* Face presentation         

* Fetal coagulopathy

* Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: 112. A 60-year-old male is brought to the hospital for a routine check-up. He has a history of drinking whisky every evening for the past 30 years. Investigations reveal deranged LFT. Which of the following regions of the hepatic lobule would be the first to show morphological changes in this patient?
questions.solution:
The centrilobular zone, i.e, Zone 3, is the first region to show morphological changes in alcoholic liver disease. 

Based on blood flow, the liver parenchyma can be divided into three zones.

* Zone 1 - Periportal (around portal triad)

* Zone 2 - Midzonal parenchyma

* Zone 3 - Centrilobular (around hepatic vein)

The centrilobular zone is first to be affected, and the changes then extend outward toward the portal tracts as the injury increases in severity. A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule, indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation, is given below.

questions.text: 113. In India, dying declaration is accepted under
questions.solution:
In India, a dying declaration is accepted under BSA Section 26A (IEA section 32).

Other options:

Option A: BSA Section 142(2) (IEA section 139) deals with cross-examination of a witness.

Option C: BNS Section 106 (IPC 304A) describes the punishment for causing death by an act of negligence.

Option D: BSA Section 39(1) (IEA section 45): It deals with the opinion of experts.

questions.text: 114. Which of the following does not cause opening of the eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Tensor tympani does not open the eustachian tube.

Muscles of the Eustachian tube:

Muscle Nerve supply Action
Tensor veli palatini/ Dilator tubae Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve Opens the tube
Levator veli palatini Pharyngeal plexus (cranial XI through X) Opens & lifts the tube
Salpingopharyngeus Pharyngeal plexus (cranial XI through Vagus) Opens the tube


Sensory & parasympathetic supply to the Eustachian tube is by the Glossopharyngeal Nerve.

questions.text:
115. Which of the following are used for performing a personality test on a person?

* Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory test

* Rorschach inkblot test

* Thematic apperception test

* Bender Gestalt test

* Sentence completion test
questions.solution:
The personality tests among the ones mentioned above are- the Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory test, Rorschach inkblot test, thematic Apperception Test, and sentence completion test 

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory test - MMPI - It is an objective personality test. It contains true or false type questions on a variety of issues.

Rorschach inkblot test - Here, the patient is asked to interpret their perception of a pattern formed on paper/card by an inkblot, and a psychological interpretation is made.

Thematic apperception test - It is a projective psychological test where the patient is given ambiguous test material. Personality assessment is made based on the interpretation of an artistic image by the patient.

Sentence completion test - It is a semistructured projective technique where the patient is asked to complete a sentence in meaningful ways, which can be used for assessment.

Statement 4: Bender Gestalt test is a neuropsychological test, not a personality test. The test involves copying geometric figures. It is used for assessing the visuospatial function of the patient.

Pearl PM0237: Neuropsychological tests

The neuropsychiatric evaluation combines information from neurological, neuropsychological testing, and mental status examinations.

The following are some common neuropsychological screening tests and test batteries: 

* Wisconsin card sorting test

* Wechsler memory scale

* PGI memory scale

* Bender Gestalt test or BG test

* Benton visual retention test or BVRT

* Luria-Nebraska neuropsychological battery

* Halstead-Reitan neuropsychological test battery

Pearl PM0238: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 


 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)


 



 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)


The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.



 

Sentence Completion Test

questions.text: 116. A 50-year-old female patient presents with a swelling near the umbilicus. Abdominal examination reveals a non-tender, fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, with a zone of resonance around the swelling. CT abdomen reveals a unilocular, thin-walled, and cystic mass. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Removal of the cyst and related intestines

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old female patient presenting with a non-tender, fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, with a zone of resonance around, is suggestive of a mesenteric cyst. CT imaging revealed a unilocular, thin-walled cyst is characteristic of a chylolymphatic cyst. The best next step in the management of this patient would be complete enucleation. 

Mesenteric cysts occur most commonly in middle-aged adults and are twice as common in women. Although they are rare, the chylolymphatic type is the most common variant, and it arises in congenitally misplaced lymphatic tissue. The most common presentation is a painless abdominal swelling near the umbilicus. There may be associated attacks of abdominal pain resulting from the temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of the bowel narrowed by the cyst.

On examination, the swelling is fluctuant and moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery (Tillaux’s sign). There is a characteristic zone of resonance around the cyst. 

Ultrasonography and CT scans of the abdomen are used for diagnosis. Chylolymphatic cysts have a blood supply independent from that of the adjacent intestine. Hence, they can be removed by enucleation.

Other options:

Option A: Removal of the cyst and related intestines is usually done for enterogenous cysts. They arise either from a diverticulum of the mesenteric border of the intestine or from duplication of the intestine. Characteristically, they are usually thick-walled when compared to chylolymphatic cysts. Since they have a common blood supply with the intestine, the removal of enterogenous cysts requires resection of the related portion of the intestine.

Option C: Observation and serial imaging is not indicated for mesenteric cysts due to the chances of complications if left untreated. These complications include: 

* torsion of that portion of the mesentery containing the cyst

* rupture of the cyst

* hemorrhage into the cyst

* infection

Option D: Tissue biopsy has no role in the management of mesenteric cysts. This is usually indicated for tumors of the mesentery. The presentation and characteristic clinical findings make it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: 117. A 32-year-old patient has iris as shown below on clinical examination. This is known as
questions.solution:
The image shows that one sector of the iris differs from the other, i.e different colours of sectors of the same iris. This is termed as Heterochromia iridis.

Heterochromia iridum Color of one iris differs from the other, i.e different color of the two iris
Heterochromia iridis One sector of the iris differs from the other, i.e different color of sectors of the same iris
Corectopia Abnormally eccentrically placed pupil
Polycoria More than one pupil

Congenital coloboma Absence of the tissue of iris, ciliary body, and choroid

questions.text: 118. A 48-year-old non-diabetic obese man presented for routine follow-up. Laboratory tests showed dyslipidemia and a vitamin preparation was prescribed to him as a lipid-lowering agent. After two weeks, he developed flushing and pruritis, along with skin irritation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the vitamin implicated in this scenario?

choices.text: Deficiency of this vitamin causes pellagra
It is an important constituent of coenzymes NAD and NADP
60 mg of this dietary vitamin  is equivalent to 1 mg of tryptophan
Involved in ADP-ribosylation of proteins and DNA repair mechanism

questions.solution:
The vitamin used as a lipid-lowering agent is nicotinic acid (niacin or vitamin B3). 1 mg of niacin is equivalent to 60 mg of tryptophan and not vice versa.

Niacin is a water-soluble B-complex vitamin. It is an important constituent of co-enzymes NAD and NADP, which are active in ADP–ribose transfer reactions involved in DNA repair. The liver can synthesise niacin from the essential amino acid tryptophan, requiring 60 mg of tryptophan to make 1 mg of niacin.

Niacin reduces lipolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and reduces hepatic triglyceride synthesis. It causes a reduction in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL. It is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein(a) levels significantly.

The toxic effects of niacin include:

* Flushing, associated with skin dryness, pruritus, paresthesia, and headache. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Premedication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms (as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins).

* Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

* Hepatic toxicity, which presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.

* Fulminant hepatitis (requires liver transplantation).

* Glucose intolerance (In patients with diabetes mellitus, niacin should be used cautiously because niacin-induced insulin resistance can cause severe hyperglycemia)

* Hyperuricemia

* Macular edema and macular cysts.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra which presents with diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and if untreated, death. Hyperpigmentation and scaly plaques are seen in photo-exposed areas in dermatitis. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck. Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can also cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. 

The below image shows casal's paint necklace seen in niacin deficiency.

questions.text: 119. Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as _________
questions.solution:
Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid, seen in Graves' ophthalmopathy, is known as Gifford's sign.

The most frequently affected extraocular muscle in Graves' ophthalmopathy is the inferior rectus.

Classification: Acronym ‘NOSPECS’:

* Class 0: No signs and symptoms

* Class 1: Only signs, no symptoms. Signs are limited to lid retraction with or without lid lag and mild proptosis

* Class 2: Soft tissue involvement with signs of class 1 and symptoms including lacrimation, photophobia, lid or conjunctival swelling

* Class 3: Proptosis is well established

* Class 4: Extraocular muscle involvement (limitation of movements and diplopia)

* Class 5: Corneal involvement (exposure keratitis)

* Class 6: Sight loss due to optic nerve involvement with disc pallor or papilloedema

Pearl PM1781: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid


The image given below shows Dalrymple's sign in the right eye.

questions.text: 120. A 4-year-old boy presents with delayed language skills; however, his other developmental milestones are progressing normally. There is no loss of previously acquired milestones. What is the most likely developmental phenomenon?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the child shows a lag in language skills while the other developmental milestones are normal, which indicates developmental dissociation.

Developmental dissociation refers to a situation where there is an uneven development across different domains, such as motor, cognitive, language, and social skills, without any loss of previously acquired milestones.

Other Options:

Option B: Developmental deviance refers to abnormal patterns of skill acquisition that deviate from the typical developmental trajectory. Children with cerebral palsy may show early standing with support secondary to increased extensor tone.

Option C: Developmental regression involves the loss of previously acquired milestones, as seen in Rett syndrome.

Option D: Global developmental delay refers to delays in multiple domains (e.g., language, motor, cognitive) identified before the age of 5, as seen in Down syndrome or metabolic disorders.

questions.text: 121. A patient was brought to the ER with nausea,vomiting , breathlessness for 2 hours after ingestion of insecticide. On examination there is pin- point pupil and kerosene like smell emitting from the patient. Which of the following is not correct regarding the management of this patient

choices.text: Activated charcoal has no proven therapeutic role
Atropine is the antidote of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient with nausea, vomiting, breathlessness, kerosene-like odor, and pinpoint pupils suggests organophosphate poisoning. Atropine does not reverse the respiratory muscle weakness caused by the organophosphates.

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist, and it competitively blocks the acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. It does not bind to nicotinic receptors, it is ineffective in treating nicotinic symptoms like respiratory depression and neuromuscular dysfunction.

Organophosphates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. It is absorbed by inhalation or through the skin. Mucous membranes and the gastrointestinal tract are also the sites for absorption. Organophosphate poisoning is the most common method of suicide involving insecticide consumption. 

Symptoms of organophosphorus poisoning are:

* Muscarinic symptoms:

* Emesis, diarrhea

* Bronchoconstriction simulating bronchial asthma

* Dyspnoea, cough, cyanosis

* Bradycardia

* Miosis (pin point pupil)

* Increased salivation, sweating, lacrimation (Chromolacryorrhoea), micturition

* Nicotinic symptoms:

* Striated muscle weakness, areflexia

* Weakness of respiratory muscles

* Sympathetic ganglia- Hypertension.

* CNS symptoms:

* Irritability

* Confusion

* Fine tremors

Diagnosis is by RBC choline esterase level estimation. It is helpful in diagnosis but has no prognostic significance.

Treatment involves prompt decontamination and airway management. Gastric lavage may be performed using tap water, with or without potassium permanganate (KMnO₄), but activated charcoal should not be used. Atropine is the primary antidote and is highly effective in reversing peripheral muscarinic symptoms and, at higher doses, CNS effects. However, it does not counteract nicotinic symptoms such as respiratory muscle weakness. Oximes, when used early, are beneficial as they act more effectively on nicotinic sites.

questions.text: 122. A 12-year-old boy comes with fever, malaise, and flaccid paraplegia of 4 days. How are the fecal samples for diagnosis transported?

choices.text: 4 samples, sent within 72 hours of collection
2 samples, sent within 48 hours of collection
2 samples, sent within 72 hours of collection
4 samples, sent within 48 hours of collection

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests acute flaccid paralysis. 

Fecal samples of all cases of acute flaccid paralysis are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8 degree Celsius. This is known as the Reverse Cold Chain, done as a part of gold standard polio surveillance. 

‘Adequate’ stool specimens are two stool specimens of sufficient quantity for laboratory analysis, collected at least 24 hours apart, within 14 days after the onset of paralysis, and arriving in the laboratory by reverse cold chain and with proper documentation

There are four steps under AFP surveillance:

*  Finding and reporting children with AFP: 

* The staff in all health facilities should report every case of AFP in any child less than 15 years of age.

* The surveillance system of the country should be able to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1,00,000 children under 15 years of age, even in the absence of polio.

* Transporting stool samples for analysis:

* All children with AFP should be tested for wild poliovirus.

* The fecal samples are used to test for polio.

* The specimens should be collected within the first two weeks after the onset of paralysis since the highest concentration of the poliovirus is found during this period.

* Two specimens taken 24-48 hours apart are required.

* The specimens are stored at 4-8°C and the specimens should reach the laboratory within 72 hours of collection.

* Isolating poliovirus:

* Isolation of the virus followed by distinguishing between wild and vaccine-related poliovirus.

* If wild type is isolated, then the virologists identify which of the two surviving types is involved.

* Mapping the virus:

* If the wild type of virus is found, the genetic makeup of the virus is further studied and is compared with the reference bank of known polioviruses to know about the geographical origin of the virus.

* Once the geographical area is identified, the source of the importation virus can be known. Immunization strategies can be determined accordingly.

Environmental Surveillance involves testing sewage and other samples from the environment for poliovirus. It can confirm wild poliovirus infection in the absence of cases. It provided supplementary surveillance data. Ad-hoc environmental surveillance, especially in polio-free zones gives information on the international spread. 

Surveillance Indicators 

* Completeness of reporting- At least 80% of expected routine (weekly or monthly) AFP surveillance reports should be received on time, including zero reports where no AFP cases are seen. The distribution of reporting sites should be representative of the geography and demography of the country

* Sensitivity of surveillance- At least one case of non-polio AFP should be detected annually per 100000 population aged <15 years. In endemic regions, to ensure even higher sensitivity, this rate should be two per 100000.

* Completeness of case investigation- All AFP cases should have a full clinical and virological investigation with at least 80% of AFP cases having ‘adequate’ stool specimens collected.

* Completeness of follow-up- At least 80% of AFP cases should have a follow-up examination for residual paralysis 60 days after the onset of paralysis

* Laboratory performance- All AFP case specimens must be processed in a WHO-accredited laboratory within the Global Polio Laboratory Network (GPLN)

 

The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following:

* Non-polio enteroviruses

* West Nile virus

* Guillan–Barre syndrome

* Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: 123. A 22-year-old man has a history of diarrhea, stools sticking to the toilet pane, and weight loss for the past 2 years. The patient now presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following is the best initial test to order for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of malabsorption with an image showing multiple, erythematous macules and papules over the abdomen (dermatitis herpetiformis) is suggestive of celiac disease. The best initial test to order for a patient with suspected celiac disease is anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG).

Celiac disease is a disorder characterised by an immunological response to gluten, causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa and malabsorption of nutrients. The typical symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The celiac disease–specific antibodies are anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies, endomysial antibodies (EMA), and antibodies against deamidated forms of gliadin peptides. HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 are present in most patients with celiac disease.

Complications of the disease include deficiencies of iron (most common), thiamine, vitamin B12, calcium, and vitamin D. Apart from this, patients can also present with osteoporosis, which can be reversed by a gluten-free diet, short stature, arthritis, and arthralgia. Extraintestinal manifestations include cardiomyopathy, erythema nodosum, dermatitis herpetiformis, peripheral neuropathies, irritability, and cerebellar ataxia. 

Endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is used as a confirmatory test to diagnose celiac disease and not as an initial test in suspected cases.

questions.text: 124. A 62-year-old man with a severe headache is brought to the emergency department by his son, who noticed that the patient's left eye had moved down and out. The patient is awake upon arrival to the ER and still complains of a headache. Examination reveals nuchal rigidity with no other neurological deficit. CT scan confirms a subarachnoid hemorrhage. What is the Hunt-Hess grade for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is awake upon examination, with a headache, nuchal rigidity, and features suggestive of 3rd cranial nerve palsy (left eye moved down and out). This patient has a subarachnoid hemorrhage of Hunt-Hess grade 2.

The Hunt-Hess clinical grading system for subarachnoid haemorrhage 
GRADE CLINICAL PRESENTATION
0 Asymptomatic, unruptured aneurysm
1 Awake, asymptomatic or mild headache: mild nuchal rigidity
2 Awake; moderate to severe headache, cranial nerve palsy( eg, cranial nerve III or IV), nuchal rigidity
3 Lethargic; mild focal neurologic deficit ( eg, pronator drift)
4 Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity or vegetative disturbance
5 Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity

questions.text: 125. Which of the following derivatives of Ricinus communis plant is not toxic?
questions.solution:
Oil derived from the seeds of the Ricinus plant is not toxic.

Ricinus communis is the castor plant. The entire plant is poisonous. The seeds are poisonous, containing the toxin, ricin. The unbroken seeds are non-poisonous. Toxin is released only if the seeds are crushed. Castor oil contains ricinoleic acid but not toxalbumen and is not poisonous as it does not contain ricin. Castor oil is used as a purgative.

Ricin has a binding protein that allows it to gain access to the endoplasmic reticulum in gastrointestinal mucosal cells, leading to severe diarrhoea. It can be absorbed through ingestion, inhalation, injection and through skin contact.

questions.text: 126. A 5-year-old boy has been brought to the physician following a drop in school performance, personality changes, and behavioral difficulties. After thorough investigations, he is diagnosed with metachromatic leukodystrophy. The accumulation of which of the following lipids is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The accumulation of sulfogalactocerebroside is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy. 

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is a serious condition and causes death within 5-6 years in the early-onset form.

Clinical manifestations of the diseases can be categorised by the age of disease onset:

* Late infantile-onset: Occurs in children < 30 months of age. Typically, early milestones are met, followed by a progressive regression of motor skills, ataxia, dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity, hyporeflexia, extensor plantar posturing, and optic atrophy. Accounts for a majority of the cases.

* Juvenile onset: Occurs between 30 months and puberty. Early milestones are met, followed by psychomotor regression, intellectual decline in the form of dropped school performance, behavioural difficulties, and personality changes.

* Adult-onset: This type shows neurocognitive and neuropsychiatric difficulties. Patients may have dysesthesias like peripheral neuropathy, psychosis, schizophrenia, or seizures.

Other options

Option A: Galactosylceramide accumulation occurs in Krabbe’s leukodystrophy.

Option C: Sphingomyelin accumulation occurs in Niemann-Pick disease

Option D: Globoside accumulation occurs in Sandhoff's disease.

questions.text: 127. The given image shows the synthesis and release of GABA in the nerve terminal. Identify the drug that acts at site A.
questions.solution:
The drug that acts at site 'A' is baclofen.

Baclofen is a centrally acting muscle relaxant. It is an analogue of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord, where it decreases the release of excitatory neurotransmitters.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief. It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically. Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the α/γ interface of the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the frequency of the opening of the chloride channel. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone.

Option B: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used as an adjunct therapy for partial seizures with or without secondary generalization.

Option D: Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic drug that acts by binding to α2δ protein. It is used in focal onset seizures, neuropathic pains like post-herpetic neuralgia, and neuropathic pain. The most common adverse effects seen with gabapentin are increased drowsiness, ataxia, and fatigue.



Pearl PM1697: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

questions.text: 128. A 57-year-old man is diagnosed with parathyroid adenoma. He complains of constipation, bone pain, lethargy, and low mood. Which of the following features can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. Pathological fractures can be seen in this condition.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the important causes of hypercalcemia and is characterised by an increase in the levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). They mainly present with bone pain or pathological fractures. Other common complaints of hypercalcemia include difficulty concentrating, depression, constipation, peptic ulcer, lethargy, and increased urinary output.

Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased excretion of phosphate in the urine, leading to decreased levels of serum phosphate. ECG may show arrhythmias and a short QT interval.

Pearl PM1599: Causes of Hypercalcemia

* Parathyroid-Related

* Primary hyperparathyroidism

* Adenoma(s)

* Multiple endocrine neoplasia

* Carcinoma

* Lithium therapy

* Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

* Malignancy-Related

* Solid tumour with metastases (breast)

* Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)

* Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)

* Vitamin D–Related

* Vitamin D intoxication

* ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :

* Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases

* Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency

* Associated with high bone turnover

* Hyperthyroidism

* Immobilization

* Thiazides

* Vitamin A intoxication

* Fat necrosis

* Associated with renal failure

* Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism

* Aluminium intoxication

* Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: 129. Formation of NAPQI from acetaminophen is catalysed by:
questions.solution:
Formation of NAPQI from acetaminophen is catalysed by CYP2E1.

CYP2E1 catalyses the formation of hepatotoxic N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) from acetaminophen and paracetamol. It also catalyses the oxidation of alcohol and halothane. Chronic alcoholism induces this isoenzyme.

Glutathione stores support detoxification of the NAPQI produced by therapeutic doses of acetaminophen. Following an acetaminophen overdose, conjugation becomes saturated, resulting in increased metabolism through CYP2E1. Glutathione stores become depleted and are insufficient to detoxify the NAPQI produced. NAPQI accumulates and is responsible for the hepatotoxic effects due to acetaminophen overdose.

questions.text: 130. Which of the following types of interactions is responsible for the stability of the protein structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins. They owe their stability to hydrogen bonds formed between two adjacent beta-sheets.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures:

* Primary

* The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.

* Secondary

* The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.

* Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.

* Alpha helix - It is the most common and stable secondary structure as a result of hydrogen bonds, supplemented by Van der Waal interactions.

* Beta-sheets - They derive their stability from hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygens and amide hydrogens of peptide bonds between adjacent sheets.

* Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.

* Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of the polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.

*  Tertiary

* This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.

* An example of a tertiary structure is domain. These are the areas/structures of a protein that are capable of performing a particular chemical or physical task, for example, binding to a molecule, acting as a receptor, etc. 

* Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.

*  Quaternary

* It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein

questions.text: 131. A 55-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. Which of the following is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: Retrograde ejaculation is a  significant side effect.
It causes significant changes in blood pressure.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests benign prostatic hyperplasia. The true statement regarding tamsulosin is retrograde ejaculation is a significant side effect.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes the blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Major side effects are dizziness and retrograde ejaculation. In patients taking tamsulosin, floppy iris has been encountered during cataract surgery. Postural hypotension is a rare side-effect of this drug. It does not promote prostatic apoptosis like terazosin and doxazosin.

Pearl PM2436: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: 132. The blood in systemic arteries has a PO2 of 70mm Hg, while the PO2 in alveolar blood is 73mm Hg. Which of the following explains this difference in the partial pressure of oxygen?
questions.solution:
The difference in the partial pressure of oxygen, that is, PO2, is slightly lower in the systemic arteries compared to the PO2 in freshly oxygenated blood is due to a physiological shunt. 

The total quantitative amount of shunted blood per minute is called the physiological shunt. This physiological shunt is measured in clinical pulmonary function laboratories by analysing the concentration of O2 in both mixed venous blood and arterial blood. The greater the physiological shunt, the greater is the amount of blood that fails to be oxygenated as it passes through the lungs. The saturation of haemoglobin also decreases by 0.5%.

The causes of the physiological shunt are:

* There are anastomoses between the bronchial capillaries, the pulmonary capillaries and veins. Some of the bronchial blood enters the bronchial veins, some enters the pulmonary capillaries and veins, bypassing the right ventricle.

* Blood flows from the coronary arteries into the chambers of the left side of the heart. 

Other options:

Option A: A pathological shunt is a shunt that has no role in the physiological function of a system; an example would be a persistent ductus arteriosus.

Option B: Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of all the space of the respiratory system other than the alveoli, which do not participate in gas exchange.

Option D: Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space.

questions.text: 133. During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child is brought to the vaccination camp. What would you do?

choices.text: Proceed with the immunization of the child for measles
Give half of the dose of usual vaccination
No vaccination is given as the child is less than 9 months
Give the vaccine only if the child develops symptoms

questions.solution:
In the setting of a measles epidemic, we proceed with immunization of measles for this child.

The scheduled age for receiving the first dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months. The second dose is given between 15 - 18 months of age such that the minimum interval between the 2 doses is 4 weeks.  A supplementary dose can be given at the age of  6 months for the following cases:

* As a part of intensified service delivery during a measles outbreak 

* In places where the risk of measles among infants < 9 months of age remains high (endemic countries experiencing regular outbreaks)

* Individual infants at high risk of contracting measles (history of contact with known cases)

* Infants traveling to countries experiencing measles outbreaks

* Infants who are known to be HIV-infected or exposed 

Infants immunized between 6 months should further receive doses 1 and 2 according to the national schedule. Thus in the given case, this infant will be immunized at 6 months due to the epidemic and then receive the regular doses at 9 and 15-18 months of age.

questions.text: 134. A middle-aged woman develops hoarseness following injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve during total thyroidectomy. On laryngoscopic examination, the left vocal cord is found to be in the paramedian position. What is the best management in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of unilateral vocal cord paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. The treatment of choice in this condition is speech therapy, if no improvement then medialization of the vocal cord is done.

Unilateral vocal cord paralysis is commonly seen following thyroid surgery (both recurrent and external laryngeal nerves of one side are affected). It results due to paralysis of all the muscles of the larynx on one side, except the inter arytenoid, which receives innervation from the opposite side.

Treatment includes speech therapy and medialization of vocal cords by injection of Teflon paste lateral to the paralyzed cord (type I thyroplasty).

Thyroplasty is a surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki's classification of thyroplasty includes:

* Type I: It is the medialization of the vocal cord. This is done in unilateral vocal cord palsy. (option B)

* Type II: It is lateralization of the vocal cord and is used to improve the airway. This is done in bilateral abductor palsy. (option A)

* Type III: It is used to shorten or relax the vocal cord. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from female to male.

* Type IV: It is used to lengthen or tighten the vocal cord and elevate the pitch. This is done in those who have undergone gender transformation from male to female.

Other options:

Options A and C: Tracheostomy and lateralization of the vocal cord (type 2 thyroplasty) are done in case of bilateral abductor paralysis. Patients usually present with dyspnea and stridor. Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position compromising the airway.

Option D: Epiglottopexy is the procedure done for bilateral vocal cord paralysis. Patients present with cough and choking fits due to inhalation of food and pharyngeal secretions.

Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy


Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.
