questions.text: 136. A female patient presents with complaints of itchy rashes over her knuckles and sun exposed areas of neck and chest as shown below, worsening over the last 2 months. She admits to difficulty in getting up from chair and using stairs. Which of the following is incorrect with respect to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding shown in the image is Gottron's papules and shawl sign. The given scenario of a patient with proximal muscle weakness and rash is highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Muscle biopsy done as part of investigation and is associated with perimysial and not endomysial infiltrates (option C)

Patients with dermatomyositis will show one or more of the following autoantibodies : antinuclear antibody (ANA), extractable nuclear antigen (ENA), double‐stranded DNA (dsDNA), lupus anticoagulant, complement levels, anticardiolipin antibodies and β2‐glycoprotein 1 antibodies and anti-P155 antibodies in case of juvenile dermatomyositis (option A), which may be associated with myositis related cancer in the future.

Myositis is the inflammation of the muscle hence the enzyme creatine kinase which presents within muscles will be released, causing elevated levels (option B)

Electromyography to assess muscle function and MRI to detect muscle edema can also be done along with pulmonary function test to look for interstitial lung disease, which is the major cause of mortality in patients with dermatomyositis.

It shows excellent response to corticosteroid therapy (option D) which is the first line along with disease modifying anti-rheumatoid agents (DMARDS). Topical steroids with topical tacrolimus proves beneficial for skin-limited disease.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of dermatomyositis:

* Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads

* Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints, as shown in the image below.



Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as shown below



* Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds

* Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer

* Less common manifestations include: Facial swelling, malignancy, erythroderma, lichen planus.

Pearl PM1989: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis

Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No

Pearl PM0185: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

* Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.

* Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”

* Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: 137. Which of the following muscles of the perineal body is unpaired?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal muscles of the anal canal are unpaired.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body. They are:

* Two unpaired 

* External anal sphincter

* Longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal

* Four paired

* Bulbospongiosus

* Superficial transverse perinei

* Deep transverse perinei

* Levator ani

The perineal body is the central fibrous skeleton of the perineum. It is situated in the medial plane about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of the penis. In females, sphincter urethro-vaginalis is also attached to the perineal body. Perineal body has a pyramidal shape in males and a wedge shape in females.

The perineal body is innervated by the perineal nerve, the larger and inferior terminal branch of the perineal pudendal nerve. It is directed forward under the internal pudendal artery. 

The perineal body supports the pelvic organs in females and it may get damaged during parturition or childbirth. This may result in prolapse of :

* Urinary bladder

* Uterus

* Ovaries

* Rectum

The image below shows the muscles of the perineum:



Pearl PM1349: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum


Pearl PM2366: Perineal Body



The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani


Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: 138. A neonate had white spots scattered over the face as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Milia.

Milia are superficial epidermal inclusion cysts that contain laminated keratinized material. Milia occurs mainly in the face and around the nose. Usually they exfoliate spontaneously without scarring in neonates.

Option A: Nevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

Option B: Bohn's nodules are retention cysts in the gums. 

Option D: Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands.

Pearl PM2213: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 



 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 



 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.



 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands



 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.



 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.



 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.



 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.



 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.



 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.



 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: 139. A 40-year-old teacher complains of difficulty holding paper between her thumb and index finger. On examination, he flexes the thumb at the interphalangeal joint while trying to grip the paper. Which of the following muscles is involved in the compensation movement of the thumb?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates a positive Froment’s test characterized by the difficulty of the patient to hold paper between the thumb and index finger. This results in the compensatory flexion of the thumb at the interphalangeal joint while attempting to grip the paper, facilitated by the Flexor pollicis longus.

The underlying cause of this issue is the weak adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve. To compensate for the weakness in the adductor pollicis, the flexor pollicis longus, which is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. This compensatory mechanism highlights the involvement of different nerves in the hand’s intricate function during gripping tasks.

The image below shows how Froment's test is performed.



Other options: 

Option B: Froment’s test evaluates the adductor pollicis, innervated by the ulnar nerve. This muscle is weak in positive froment test and not compensatory.

Option C: The abductor pollicis longus is radial nerve-innervated and is unrelated to the test.

Option D: Flexor pollicis brevis flexes the thumb in the metacarpophalangeal joint and not at the interphalangeal joint.

questions.text: 140. A junior resident was conducting a study on factors affecting dead space. In which of the following posture and airway position would he notice the maximum increase in dead space?
questions.solution:
A junior resident would notice a maximum increase in dead space in Upright posture with Neck extension.

Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

* Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+alveolar dead space.

* Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.

* Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

questions.text: 141. A 20-year old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after a blunt trauma to the chest. ECG of the patient shows the following findings. Which of the following components of JVP is expected to be prominent?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Prominent x descent in JVP is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Acute cardiac tamponade develops very quickly, often in a matter of minutes, and typically presents with signs of cardiogenic shock. It is most commonly triggered by trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or complications from invasive cardiac procedures. In contrast, subacute cardiac tamponade progresses gradually over several days to weeks and is usually associated with pericarditis of neoplastic, uremic, or unknown (idiopathic) origin.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

* Tachycardia and hypotension

* Pericardial rub

* Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 

* Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of :

* hypotension

* muffled heart sounds, and 

* elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent



ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.



The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.



In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid.

Pearl PM2416: JVP waveform and the abnormalities



1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation


 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade


 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation


 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: 142. A 22-year-old mother wants to get her 2-day-old newborn to be screened for hypothyroidism as she had read on the internet that it is a common cause of preventable mental retardation. Which of the following strategies is most commonly followed for the screening process?

choices.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.solution:
The most commonly followed strategy for newborn screening of congenital hypothyroidism is using a dried blood sample and screening it first for TSH.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Screening of children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important, as early diagnosis and treatment can help in normal intellectual development. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome.

Screening is usually done between day 2 - day 4 postnatally using dried blood samples for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based approach. Although the TSH-based approach is better, it doesn't identify central hypothyroidism, which can be identified by the T4-first approach. But, the T4-based approach misses out on the cases of compensated hypothyroidism.

The incidence of congenital hypothyroidism is 4 times higher in India compared to western countries. Thyroid dysgenesis has emerged as the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India.

Clinical features of hypothyroidism:

Congenital Acquired
Open posterior fontanel Growth retardation
Umbilical hernia Delayed skeletal maturation
Characteristic edematous facies Delayed dental development
Constipation Delayed puberty
Pallor Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
Hypothermia Enlarged sella
Large tongue Pseudotumor cerebri
Rough dry skin  
Hypotonia  
Large abdomen  


Management is by thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

Dried blood spots are a form of biosampling where a drop of blood is collected as a spot on a filter paper. It is most commonly used for the screening of metabolic disorders in neonates because of advantages including low volume of blood sampling, more convenient transportation, storage without special treatment, and enhanced analyte stability.

Pearl PM0786: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text:
143. Which of the following is true about Fastrach LMA?

LMA- Laryngeal mask airway
questions.solution:
Fastrach LMA (Laryngeal mask airway) allows for endotracheal intubation through the LMA device itself  i.e., it allows for guided intubation

It has an epiglottis elevating bar, handle, Endotracheal tube, pilot balloon for ET cuff, and pilot balloon for LMA cuff. It can be used multiple times. LMA devices are contraindicated in hiatal hernia as such because they cause a high risk of aspiration.



Pearl PM0179: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

* Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

* In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 

* For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 

* As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

* Oropharyngeal abscess or mass

* Poor mouth opening 

* Conditions with high risk of aspiration:

* Hiatus hernia

* Pregnancy

* Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm

* Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)

* Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text: 144. A patient has a hematocrit level of 40% and renal plasma flow of 600 mL/min. Calculate the renal blood flow.
questions.solution:
The renal blood flow is 1000 mL/min.

The amount of blood pumped to the kidney is known as the renal blood flow and is about 25% of the cardiac output. The renal blood flow is directly proportional to the pressure gradient between the renal artery and vein. The relation of renal blood flow with renal plasma flow is as given below:

Renal blood flow (RBF) = Renal plasma flow/(1-Hematocrit)

                                            = RPF / (1-Hct)

                                            = 600 / (1-0.4)

                                            = 600 / 0.6

                                            = 1000 mL/min

Pearl PM2330: Formulae in renal physiology

Term

Equation

Clearance rate

Us ×V / Ps

 

Glomerular filtration rate

Uinulin × V / Pinulin

 

Clearance ratio

Cs/Cinulin

Effective renal plasma flow

ERPF=CPAH=UPAH ×V / PPAH

 

 

Renal blood flow

Cs - clearance rate of substance “s”

EPAH  - PAH extraction ratio

ERPF - effective renal plasma flow

GFR - glomerular filtration rate

questions.text:
145. Which of the following statements are true:

* Brain and red blood cells are the primary consumers of glucose in a fasting state

* Free fatty acids released by lipolysis at adipose tissue are used by the heart, skeletal muscle, and liver cells inthe  fasting state

* In a well-fed state, muscles and liver become consumers of glucose, replenishing their glycogen reserves

* In a fasting state, the consumption of branched-chain amino acids by the brain increases

* In a fasting state, liver cells metabolize free fatty acids to ketone bodies, which can be exclusively utilized by liver cells
questions.solution:
In the fasting state, glucose continues to be consumed primarily by the brain and red blood cells. This glucose is supplied by hepatic glycogenolysis during early fasting and by gluconeogenesis during prolonged fasting. Free fatty acids formed from lipolysis of adipocytes are used as fuel by the heart muscle, skeletal muscle, and liver cells. Liver cells metabolize free fatty acids into ketone bodies which can be utilized by peripheral tissues.

In the well-fed state, the rate of glucose consumption by the brain and red blood cells is similar to that in the fasting state. Lipolysis in adipose tissue slows down in the fed state, and muscles and the liver consume glucose for energy and glycogenesis. 

The differences between fed and fasting state is shown in the table below: 

Feature Fed state Fasting state
Main Glucose Source Dietary glucose Liver via glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis
Fuel in brain  Glucose

Short term: Glucose;

Long term: Glucose + Ketone bodies
Fuel in skeletal muscle  Glucose + Fatty acids

Short term: Fatty acids;

Long term: Ketone bodies + Branched chain amino acids
Fuel in cardiac muscle  Glucose + Pyruvate

Short term: Fatty acids;

Long term: Ketone bodies
Fuel in adipose tissues Fatty acids + Glucose

Short term: Fatty acids;

Long term: Fatty acids + Ketone bodies
Fat Metabolism Lipolysis suppressed; minimal fatty acid release  Adipose tissue releases fatty acids via lipolysis
Ketone Body Production Minimal Produced by liver from fatty acids
Glucose use  Constant in RBC and CNS Constant in RBC and CNS
Muscle metabolism Muscle takes up glucose and stores as glycogen Muscle breaks down protein to amino acids for gluconeogenesis
Glycogen Glucose stored as glycogen in liver and muscle Glycogen stores gradually deplete
Fat Storage Excess glucose stored as triacylglycerol in adipose tissue Triacylglycerol stores mobilized for energy
Hormonal State High insulin, low glucagon Low insulin, high glucagon; increased sympathetic and hormonal signals
Blood Glucose Regulation Tightly controlled by insulin Maintained by hepatic glucose output to protect CNS

questions.text:
146. At the genetics clinic, a child with dysmorphic facies, as shown below, is brought by the parents, who have several doubts about his condition. Which of the following is true about the child’s condition?

* There is a 50% chance of inheritance

* IQ is usually normal

* Mongoloid slant is seen

* Associated with cleft palate

* Deafness is common
questions.solution:
The typical dysmorphic appearance of the child is highly suggestive of Treacher-Collins syndrome/ Mandibulofacial dysostosis.

It is an Autosomal dominant disorder (50% chance of inheritance) due to abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch. It is characterized by:

* Craniofacial bone defects - Involves mandible (causing micrognathia), maxilla, and zygomatic arches hypoplasia

* Ear defects - Involve the external ear (microtia), atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles- malleus & incus leading to bilateral conductive deafness.

* Eye defects - Down-slanting palpebral fissures, aka Anti-mongoloid slant, seen,  and lower eyelid colobomas

* Choanal atresia

* Mouth - macrostomia with high arched palate or cleft. Dental malocclusions are common. The teeth may be missing or hypoplastic.

* Cardiovascular system - VSD, ASD, PDA

* Characteristically, IQ is preserved in these children.

questions.text: 147. You see a TV commercial that encourages people to consume cooked eggs every day. What is the Net protein utilization (NPU) of an egg, and which vitamin is it deficient in?
questions.solution:
The net protein utilization (NPU) of the egg is 100 and the egg is deficient in Vitamin C and Carbohydrates.

A 60 gm egg contains-

* 6 g Fat

* 6 g Protein

* 30 mg Calcium

* 1.5 mg Iron

* 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Eggs protein has all 9 amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions, and hence, it is considered a "reference Protein". A boiled egg is nutritionally superior to a raw egg as boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing biotin. Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white (avidin) develops biotin deficiency (Option B and C).

Net protein utilization (NPU) is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body with respect to nitrogen intake. NPU is calculated as the percentage of protein retained by the body from the total protein intake. It is described as the product of the digestibility coefficient and the biological value divided by 100.

Pearl PM2154: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

* Amino acid score:

* Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.



 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:



B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 



Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: 148. A 19-year-old female with a history of sickle cell disease presents with frequent painful vaso-occlusive crises, despite being on optimized hydroxyurea therapy. The physician discusses the addition of a newer targeted therapy to reduce the frequency of crises. Which of the following drugs target the P-selectin?
questions.solution:
Crizanlizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting P-selectin

P-selectin is involved in the adhesion of sickled cells to blood vessel walls. Crizanlizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting P-selectin. It has been shown to significantly reduce the number of painful vaso-occlusive crises, even in patients already on hydroxyurea. It can be used as monotherapy or as an add-on to hydroxyurea in cases of suboptimal response.

Other options:

Option A: Voxelotor is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease. It does this by binding to haemoglobin and increasing its ability to hold oxygen, which stops the abnormal hemoglobin S from clumping together.

Option C: L-glutamine, an amino acid essential for producing NAD+ and NADH, plays a key role as an antioxidant in red blood cells. It is used in sickle cell disease to improve the redox balance of RBCs, reducing cell sickling, hemolysis, and pain crises. 

Option D: Panobinostat is an HDAC inhibitor used to treat multiple myeloma. It works by inhibiting histone deacetylase enzymes, inducing apoptosis in cancer cells through multiple mechanisms.

questions.text: 149. In a woman in active labor, the occiput of the baby is found to lie in the posterior part of the maternal pelvis towards the left side. Which of the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
The relation of the denominator (occiput, here) to the different quadrants of the pelvis as mentioned refers to the position of the fetus.

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

* Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine

* Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the uterus or pelvic brim

* Presenting part: Part of the presentation that overlies the internal os

* Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another

* Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

questions.text: 150. A young boy who is a known case of Klinefelter's syndrome presents with a painless scrotal swelling and precocious puberty. After an initial ultrasound that revealed a testicular mass, surgical removal was done. The specimen was sent for histopathological analysis; the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of a Leydig cell tumour with the biopsy findings showing the "crystalloids of Reinke".

Development of a painless testicular mass in a child with a history of Klinefelter's syndrome and precocious puberty is suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumour, like Leydig cell tumour. The biopsy shows large polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. The cytoplasm also shows rod-shaped crystals referred to as "crystalloids of Reinke" in about 25% of the patients, which confirms the diagnosis. It appears as a homogenous golden-brown tumour, which is usually less than 5cm.

Leydig cell tumours are sex-cord stromal cell tumours of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and, in some cases, estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. Leydig-cell tumours are associated with:

* Klinefelter's syndrome

* Cryptorchidism

* Hereditary leiomyomatosis

* Renal cell carcinoma syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the enzyme fumarate hydratase.

The image given below shows a Leydig cell tumour with crystalloids of Reinke.



Other options:

Option B - Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome. On microscopy, tumor cells are arranged in trabaculae to form cord-like structures and tubules, as shown below:



Option C - Yolk-sac tumor is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis also known as endodermal sinus tumor. They secrete α-fetoprotein. On microscopy, a typical lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, is seen. In half the cases, a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells is present known as Schiller-Duval bodies as shown below:



Option D - Seminoma testis is the most common germ cell tumor. They present as large, bulky tumors, without any haemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopy, seminoma cells are round to polyhedral and have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli as shown below:



Pearl PM2277: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Seminoma

* Non-seminomatous GCTs

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type

* Choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma, post-pubertal type

* Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Spermatocytic tumour

* Teratoma, prepubertal type

* Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type

* Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

* Leydig cell tumor

* Sertoli cell tumor

* Granulosa cell tumor

* Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

* Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Pearl PM2279: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor


AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Pearl PM0449: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -


 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Yolk sac tumor

* Teratocarcinoma

* Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

* Choriocarcinoma

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Teratocarcinoma

* Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)

* Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

* LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.

*  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: 151. A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense bullae associated with pruritus. The lesions began first as erythema and urticaria. Physical examination shows tense bullae on the trunk and thigh region. Direct immunofluorescence done on skin biopsy tissue is as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Immunofluorescence shows linear deposits of IgG and C3
Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosome antigens
Acantholysis is uniformly seen on histology

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with a continuous linear immunofluorescence pattern shown in the image is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk that do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. Since these antigens are not present in mucosa, mucosal involvement is not frequently seen, unlike pemphigus vulgaris. It is present in only 10% of cases.

The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. These blisters are tense and do not rupture easily and Eosinophils are present just below the basal cell layer. Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 deposits in a continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction.



Image: Direct immunofluorescence shows continuous linear pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction



Image (above) shows the fishnet pattern of immunofluorescence in pemphigus vulgaris

Pearl PM2085: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

questions.text: 152. The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of which cervical vertebrae?
questions.solution:
The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of the C4 cervical vertebra. 

The origin of the phrenic nerve or the spinal respiratory centre is mainly formed by the C4 spinal cord segment, with minor contributions from C3 and C5 segments. Thus, injury to the spinal cord above the C4 vertebral level can be rapidly fatal from disruption of cardiorespiratory regulation centres.

The commonly injured areas of the spine are include lower cervical region, thoracolumbar junction, and the upper cervical region.

questions.text:
153. The following are events involved in phototransduction in rods and cones in response to light. Arrange them in sequence.

* Decreased release of glutamate

* Activation of transducin

* Closure of cGMP-gated cation channels

* Decrease in intracellular cGMP

* Structural changes in rhodopsin
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events involved in phototransduction in rods and cones in response to light is:

* Structural changes in rhodopsin due to the incident light

* Activation of transducin

* Activation of phosphodiesterase

* Decrease in intracellular cGMP

* Closure of cGMP-gated Na+ channel

* Hyperpolarization

* Decreased release of glutamate

* Response in the bipolar cells

questions.text: 154. A 23-year-old postpartum female, who delivered a healthy baby 4 days back by normal vaginal delivery, complains of a bloody vaginal discharge. On examination, the vaginal walls & introitus are coated with discharge that has a sweetish odor. The uterus is soft and non-tender. Temp - 37 °C, PR-79/min, BP-110/70mm. Her WBC count is 10,000 cells/mm3. Which is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a postpartum female complaining of bloody vaginal discharge along with normal vitals and leukocyte count indicates a normal postpartum lochia, which requires only reassurance and observation.

Lochia is the vaginal discharge that occurs postpartum due to the sloughing of decidual tissue. It contains erythrocytes, decidual cells, epithelial cells, and bacteria. It changes in color and composition over time:

Name Color Timing after delivery

 Content
Lochia rubra Red Days 1-4 Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink Days 4-10 WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms
Lochia alba Pale White After 10th day Decidual cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterol crystals, and fat cells


Other options:

Option A and C: A vaginal swab culture & oral antibiotics are only indicated in case of puerperal sepsis. In the case of puerperal sepsis, the uterus is tender, soft & sub-involuted with a fever and raised WBC counts. The lochia is not foul-smelling & WBC levels of 10,000 cells/mm3 in this case are normal.

Option D: Curettage is indicated in the case of secondary postpartum hemorrhage due to retained placental bits. In this case, her vitals are stable & uterus is soft and nontender, indicating normal involution.

questions.text: 155. A primigravid woman in her 36th week of gestation presented with progressive jaundice, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Investigations revealed abnormal liver function tests pointing towards a diagnosis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Which of the following enzymes is most likely to be involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of fetal long-chain 3-hydroxy acyl CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) is involved in the pathogenesis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Acute fatty liver is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. It occurs either due to poor placental mitochondrial function or due to a fetal deficiency of long-chain acyl coenzyme A dehydrogenase (LCHAD).

The patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice, and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. There is hemolysis, with decreased platelets and fibrinogen. Elevated d-dimer is seen. Microscopy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration.

The condition worsens till delivery after which the hepatic dysfunction resolves. Trial of labor by induction or delivery by Cesarean is done. Intensive supportive measures including blood transfusion should be provided.

questions.text: 156. A 49-year-old male patient presented with shoulder pain on inspiration following severe blunt abdominal trauma that he sustained following road traffic accident. This sign is called:
questions.solution:
Shoulder pain on inspiration is called the Danforth sign, seen in cases of hemoperitoneum.

Other Options:

Option B: Cullen sign is the periumbilical bruising seen in hemoperitoneum.

The image below shows Cullen's sign.



Option C: Kehr's sign is the left shoulder pain when supine and pressure is placed on the left upper abdomen (seen in cases of splenic rupture).

Option D: Grey Turner sign is the local areas of discoloration around the flanks (seen in acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis)

The image below shows Grey Turner's sign.

questions.text: 157. In a normal ECG, which among the following leads would show R wave with maximal positive height?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, an R wave of maximal positive height is seen in lead V4 or V5. 

The QRS has different morphology across the chest leads because of their position on the chest wall. The relationship between the direction of vectors and the precordial leads determines the height of the R wave. This is characterized by an increase in the height of the R wave from V1 to V6.

Ventricular depolarization consists of two phases of depolarization:  

Interventricular septum-

* The first phase is a short (< 0.04 s) depolarization of the interventricular septum. It begins with a branch of the bundle of His on the left side of the septum. This causes the vector to go from the left side to the right and anteriorly.  

* During the first phase, there is a small R wave (positive deflection) in lead V1, gradually altering, across the precordial leads, to a small Q wave (negative deflection) in lead V6.

Ventricular mass- 

* The second wave involves simultaneous depolarization of both the ventricles. The left ventricle contains more muscle mass so the vector points towards the left and posteriorly.

* In the second phase, there is a deep S wave (negative deflection) in lead V1, gradually altering to an R wave (positive deflection) in lead V6. 

This changing QRS morphology from lead V1 to V6 is termed R wave progression.

R wave of maximal positive height in lead V4 and V5, as seen in the image below:



At a certain point, named the transition zone, the height of the R wave and the S wave are equal. This generally occurs around lead V3 (as seen in the image above) or V4. 

Other options: 

Option B: V1 usually has a small R wave and a deep S wave, termed rS.

Option C: Lead aVR is generally negative with an rS complex, QS complex (no R wave), or a Qr complex. 

Option D: V2 would have a similar appearance to V1 with a slightly larger R wave and a slightly smaller S wave.

Pearl PM0203: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: 158. A 45-year-old woman with skin findings as shown in the given image presents with low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive dyspnea. Her x-ray image is shown below. Which of the following features is not seen in her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image showing lupus pernio and the chest x-ray showing the garland triad/pawnbroker's sign, is suggestive of sarcoidosis. One of the features of sarcoidosis is non-caseating granulomas. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

There are two syndromes that are associated with the condition:

* Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.

* Mikulicz syndrome is the bilateral involvement of the parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematous-violaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include the following:

* Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

* Non-caseating granulomas

* Lupus pernio

* Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.



Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings.

Chest x-ray findings include the following:

* The parenchymal infiltrates are mostly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates.

* Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis.

* It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or pawnbrokers sign.

The staging of sarcoidosis is as below:

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis  




* Gallium-67 scan:

* Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

* Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).

* Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE. 

* Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. More commonly, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.

* Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.

* Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.

* Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

The mainstay of treatment is corticosteroids. Systemic therapy is indicated if multiple organs are affected. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids.

questions.text: 159. Which of the following is the most common cause of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above image is a case of ichthyosis.

It is a family of genetic disorders characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin. The commonest form ichthyosis vulgaris is due to genetic defect in the gene FLG coding for Filaggrin protein.

It is regarded as a disorder of keratinization or cornification, and it is due to abnormal epidermal differentiation or metabolism. 

Other options:

* Harlequin ichthyosis is the most devastating type of Autosomal Recessive Congenital Icthyosis.It is due to mutations of the ABCA12 genes.

* Recessive X-linked ichthyosis is the second most common ichthyosis after ichthyosis vulgaris. It is caused by deletions or mutations in the STS gene encoding the steroid sulfatase enzyme.

* Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common malignancy associated with acquired ichthyosis

Note: The presentation of acquired ichthyosis is similar to the inherited condition ichthyosis vulgaris, with prominent fish-like, relatively large scales adherent to the skin; however, the scaling in acquired disease may also be present on the palms and soles and in skin flexures.

questions.text: 160. A 15-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the right upper leg associated with pain. His radiographic image is shown below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which among the following is false?

choices.text: Radioisotope scan would show marked increase in activity
It is mostly seen on femoral or tibial metaphysis
The condition is a form of chronic osteomyelitis
Staphylococcus aureus would mostly be involved

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image showing a lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim are suggestive of Brodie's abscess which is a form of subacute osteomyelitis, not a chronic form.

The patient is usually a child or adolescent, who would present with pain and swelling on the affected limb. The temperature, WBC counts, and blood cultures are usually normal, with sometimes elevated ESR. There is often very little to suggest an infection.

The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity (Option A). The organism mostly involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. (Option D)

It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur (Option B). The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) IV for 4-5 days and followed by orally for another 6 weeks. The healing may take up to 12 months.

Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.

questions.text: 161. All are true statements regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome except__________

choices.text: It is obstruction of hepatic vein
CECT abdomen is the best investigation
Side to side porto caval shunt is a treatment modality.

questions.solution:
Hepatic venography is the best investigation for Budd-Chiari syndrome (not CECT abdomen).

Budd-Chiari syndrome: Uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. The most common presentation is ascites and abdominal discomfort.

Investigations:

* Abdominal ultrasonography with color doppler is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins.

* The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as to measure IVC pressures.

Treatment :

* Initial treatment is medical management with systemic anticoagulation. The associated portal hypertension and ascites are managed in a manner similar to that in most cirrhotic patients.

* Radiologic and surgical intervention is used when the patient is nonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and TIPS, in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferred strategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver. Surgical shunting, namely with the side-to-side portacaval shunt, turns the portal vein into a hepatic outflow tract.

questions.text: 162. Brown's syndrome involves which of the following extraocular muscles?
questions.solution:
Brown's syndrome, causing restrictive squint, involves the Superior oblique muscle.

Brown's syndrome, also known as Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome:

* It is characterised by limitation of elevation of the eye in adduction (normal elevation in abduction).

* Patients have straight eyes in the primary position and a positive forced duction test on attempts to elevate the eye in adduction.

A few other common causes of restrictive squint are:

* Duane’s retraction syndrome

* Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome

* Strabismus fixus

* Dysthyroid ophthalmopathy

* Incarceration of the extraocular muscle in a blow-out fracture of the orbit

questions.text: 163. A 65-year-old man comes to the ophthalmologist with complaints of diminished vision in the right eye for the past few months. He says that he had undergone cataract surgery 5 years back. On examination, the following finding is noted in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris. The likely diagnosis is Soemmering’s ring.

Soemmering’s ring is a type of secondary or after-cataract. It is the opacity that persists or develops after the extracapsular lens extraction. If the posterior capsule is clear and does not interfere with vision, then it requires no treatment. Thin membranous cataracts are treated with YAG-laser capsulotomy or Zeigler’s knife. Dense after-cataract requires surgical membranectomy.

Other options -

Option A) Endophthalmitis - It can be an early or late complication of cataract surgery causing severe intraocular inflammation. Patients complain of pain and vision loss, if early. Clinically, there is eyelid swelling with conjunctival injection, Marcus-Gunn pupil, hypopyon, and vitritis. Intravitreal antibiotics are the key to management. Other treatment modalities include oral antibiotics ,steroids, and pars plana vitrectomy.

Option B) Sunset syndrome - It is a late IOL-related complication after cataract surgery. It refers to inferior subluxation of the IOL.

Option C) Elschnig’s pearls refers to the accumulation of the vacuolated epithelial cells clustered like soap bubbles along with the posterior capsule.



Pearl PM2181: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

* Acute post-operative endophthalmitis

* Retained lens matter

* Corneal edema

* Wound leak and dehiscence

* Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

* Posterior capsule opacification (most common)

* Delayed-onset post-operative endophthalmitis

* Cystoid macular edema

* Secondary glaucoma

* Retinal detachment

* Intraocular lens malpositions:

* Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium

* Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation

* Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation

* Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

Pearl PM0897: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract



Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract



Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract



Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: 164. A patient with an underlying pulmonary disease develops community-acquired pneumonia. The causative organism was found to be Moraxella catarrhalis. Which of the following is the likely underlying disease?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia due to Moraxella catarrhalis is likely to be associated with underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or smoking.

The presence of certain epidemiological factors suggests possible etiological agents of community-acquired pneumonia, as given in the table below:

Factor Possible pathogen
Alcoholism S. pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, oral anaerobes
COPD and smoking S. pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis
Bronchiectasis Pseudomonas, Burkholderia, Staphylococcus aureus
Decreased level of consciousness (leading to aspiration) Oral anaerobes, gram-negative enteric bacteria
Lung abscess MRSA, oral anaerobes, Mycobacteria
Stay in a hotel or a cruise ship in the past 2 weeks Legionella
Exposure to birds Chlamydia psittaci
Exposure to rabbits Francisella


Pearl PM0150: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.


 

* The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.

* The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

* The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-

* Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)

* The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

Pearl PM1171: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

* Confusion 

* Urea (BUN) >7 mmol/L (20mg/dL)

* Respiratory rate ≥30/min 

* Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 

* Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: 165. A patient with recurrent attacks of fever and inflammation of serosal surfaces and a family history of hereditary amyloidosis was diagnosed with familial Mediterranean fever. Which cytokine is excessively produced in this condition?
questions.solution:
Familial Mediterranean fever is an auto-inflammatory syndrome associated with the excess production of the cytokine IL-1.

Familial Mediterranean fever is the most common hereditary familial amyloidosis. It is autosomal recessive and there is excessive production of cytokine IL-1 in response to inflammatory stimuli. The gene associated with this condition encodes a protein called pyrin. The amyloid fibrils here is made up of AA proteins.

Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP) is associated with the deposition of mutant transthyretin protein (TTR). 

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition. The deposition occurs as amyloid fibrils in peripheral and autonomic nerves. Mutated TTR is prone to misfolding and aggregation, and shows resistance to proteolysis.

questions.text: 166. The logo given below represents ______________
questions.solution:
The logo given above represents radiation waste.

Other logos:

* Cytotoxic waste



* Biohazard



All living things are exposed to ionizing radiation from natural and man-made radiation sources. The doses to the occupational workers shall be kept As Low As Reasonably Achievable (ALARA).

questions.text: 167. A 70-year-old man presents with symptoms characterized by abrupt, fleeting episodes of pain in the throat upon swallowing. These episodes are specifically triggered when the patient tries to consume water or expel phlegm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with difficulty swallowing, induced when sipping water and on clearing the sputum, is suggestive of a diagnosis of glossopharyngeal neuralgia.

It involves the glossopharyngeal (IX) and sometimes portions of the vagus (X) nerve. The condition resembles trigeminal neuralgia but is less common. There is no demonstrable sensory or motor deficit. It can result from vascular compression, multiple sclerosis, or tumors. It presents with intense, short-lived stabbing pain felt in areas such as the ear, base of the tongue, tonsillar fossa, or below the jaw angle.

The drug of choice is carbamazepine. If unsuccessful, surgical procedures are indicated:

* Microvascular decompression (if vascular compression is evident)

* Rhizotomy of the glossopharyngeal and vagal fibers in the jugular bulb

Other options: 

Option A: TMJ synovitis occurs due to an inflammation that can occur in either the synovium or the capsule. Frequently, individuals experience discomfort during periods of inactivity, as well as restricted mobility or discomfort when reaching the limits of their range of motion. Patients with TMJ synovitis do not typically present with stabbing symptoms in the posterior part of the tongue.

Option B: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin. It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, and smiling. Certain trigger zones are present on the face that provoke these attacks. Tactile stimuli, such as washing the face and brushing teeth, may trigger the pain. The pain usually lasts for a few seconds to 1-2 minutes.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, phenytoin, topiramate, or gabapentin are other options that may be tried if carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Option D: Sluder's neuralgia is primarily characterized by predominantly unilateral, moderately severe headaches with sensations of burning, boring, or nagging pain. The headache typically originates around the eye and the root or lateral side of the nose and may extend to the maxillary region and affect the related teeth, zygoma, mastoidal area, occiput, and, in some cases, even the shoulder and arm. Pain can manifest in either episodic form, characterized by intermittent bouts that endure for hours to days, or in a continuous manner.

Several proposed etiologies for sphenopalatine neuralgia (SN) include infection of the posterior ethmoid and sphenoidal sinus according to Sluder's theory, trauma (in which case the term "Sluder's neuropathia" is preferred), demyelination, or the existence of intranasal contact points such as a septal spine impinging on the middle turbinate.

questions.text:
168. A 62-year-old woman presented with fatigue and unrelenting severe bone discomfort. She currently resides in an old age home and has minimal exposure to sunlight. Investigations revealed low levels of vitamin D and elevated levels of PTH and ALP. A radiograph of the hip is given. What is the diagnosis?

PTH : Parathormone ALP : Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing Looser zones are suggestive of osteomalacia.

In osteomalacia, the osteoid matrix is secreted at a normal rate but the mineralization is decreased i.e, decreased mineral apposition rate and increased osteoid maturation time. Osteomalacia mainly presents with extreme fatigue and weakness along with the chance of fractures.

Lab findings reveal normal/low calcium and elevated alkaline phosphatase. 

Looser zones are the classical lesions of osteomalacia. These are due to incomplete stress fractures which heal with callus-lacking in calcium. They are thin transverse bands of rarefaction especially seen in the pelvis, the shaft of long bones such as the femur neck, and the axillary edge of the scapula.

Treatment options include calcium and vitamin D supplements along with phosphate supplements.

The image below shows Looser's zone:



Codfish vertebrae are the biconcave vertebral bodies seen in osteomalacia. They are seen in:

* Hyperparathyroidism

* Osteomalacia

* Osteoporosis

The image below shows the codfish vertebrae:



Note: Osteoporosis is characterized by normal levels of ALP (Alkaline phosphatase) and serum Phosphate levels. Looser zones are not seen in Osteoporosis. A DEXA scan is the investigation of choice in diagnosing osteoporosis and the results are reported in terms of T-score, and a score of -2.5 or lower is defined as osteoporosis

questions.text: 169. A third-year resident presents with recurrent painful lesions on his fingertip as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of vesicles and cloudy blisters at the pulp of fingers in a resident doctor is suggestive of herpetic whitlow, caused by the herpes viruses. The most appropriate drug that can be given to this patient is acyclovir.

Acyclovir is administered according to the severity:

*  Primary herpetic whitlow - Topical acyclovir

*  Recurrent herpetic whitlow/multiple sites - oral acyclovir

*  Immunocompromised patients - Intravenous acyclovir

Herpetic whitlow is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions. Clinical features include painful deep vesicles at the site of inoculation (in this case, fingertips,) which coalesce to form large bullae or a honeycomb appearance. Fever and constitutional symptoms are mild. HSV-1 and HSV-2 can cause this condition.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

* Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)

* Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. Intranuclear type A inclusion bodies may also be seen.

The image given below shows Tzanck cells.

questions.text:
170. Which of the following statements regarding Haab’s Striae are correct?

1. Not seen in juvenile glaucoma

2. Horizontal or concentric to the limbus

3. Indistinguishable from birth trauma striae

4. Persist even after control of glaucoma
questions.solution:
The statements regarding Haab’s Striae that are correct are 1, 2, and 4. 

Haab striae are tears in the Descemet’s membrane of the cornea that are seen as double ‘tram-track’ lines concentric to the limbus. They are seen in congenital glaucoma and not juvenile glaucoma (Statement 1). Haab’s striae usually persist even after the control of glaucoma (Statement 4). Haab's striae are horizontal or concentric to the limbus (Statement 2).

They can be easily distinguished from traumatic striae that are usually not concentric to the limbus (Statement 3). Vertical or oblique lines representing tears in the Descemet’s membrane are seen in birth trauma.

Congenital glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure from birth to around 3–4 years of age. The eye can progressively enlarge during this period due to its distensible wall. Symptoms often prompt detection by parents, including noticeable eye enlargement (buphthalmos), hazy corneas from stretching and swelling, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and excessive tearing. Infants may also become irritable and avoid light by burying their heads.

In the early stages, congenital glaucoma may present as a ground-glass appearance of the cornea, increased tearing, and marked photophobia. As the condition advances, discrete corneal opacities, known as Haab striae, appear due to a ruptured Descemet's membrane. The cornea and eyeball may become enlarged, the sclera may take on a bluish hue due to the underlying uveal pigment, and the cornea may adopt a globular shape. The anterior chamber becomes very deep, the lens may flatten and shift backward, and myopia is commonly observed.

Treatment options are primarily surgical, as medications are less effective. The most successful procedures include goniotomy and trabeculotomy. Both techniques aim to improve aqueous humor drainage and reduce intraocular pressure, though localization of the canal can sometimes be challenging.

questions.text: 171. The image depicts a technique used to visualise corneal topographic lesions. The technique is:
questions.solution:
Fluorescein Staining is the technique shown in the image.

Corneal Epithelial Lesions are visualised using vital dye staining techniques. Dyes used are:

* Fluorescein - to delineate areas with epithelial damage

* Rose Bengal - Stain Diseased and devitalised cells

* Alcian Blue - Stains excess mucus selectively

The image below shows rose bengal staining of the conjunctiva.



Indocyanin Green is only used in Angiography of Choroidal Vasculature.

The image below shows Indocyanine Green Angiography (ICGA).

questions.text: 172. An intern uses the following instrument to catheterize a patient. What is the size of this catheter?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is the Foley catheter having an orange-colored ring in the ballon port, indicating its size to be 16 F.

Pearl PM2278: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below

questions.text: 173. A 40-year-old male patient who works with animal hides presents with a lesion covered by a black eschar on his arm. Microscopy of the pus sample revealed bacilli, as shown in the image below. Which of the following proteins is not associated with the toxin produced by this pathogen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic bamboo stick appearance suggest Bacillus anthracis. Serum opacity factor is not a protein associated with anthrax toxin.

Serum opacity factor is a lipoproteinase produced by some M types of Streptococcus pyogenes. It causes opacity when applied to agar gel containing horse or swine serum. It is used to determine the virulence of the organism. 

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It causes zoonotic infections in humans. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of d(-)glutamic acid.

Virulence factors of B. anthracis include

* A polypeptide capsule that inhibits phagocytosis

* Anthrax toxins, which are made of three proteins

1. Edema factor/Factor I An adenylate cyclase that causes tissue edema
2. Protective antigen/Factor II Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell
3. Lethal factor/Factor III Causes tissue death


 

Clinical presentation of anthrax:

* Cutaneous anthrax: It is seen in dock workers carrying loads of hides and skin of infected animals. Hence, it is also called hide porter's disease. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops in about 1–3 days. This develops into a vesicle that later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a malignant pustule. The majority of the patients recover spontaneously, but a few may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.



* Pulmonary anthrax: It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic pneumonitis. 

* Intestinal anthrax: It is rare and is caused due to ingestion of infected animals. 

* Anthrax meningitis or meningoencephalitis: This is a fatal infection that occurs when the infection spreads to the CNS hematogenously.

Pearl PM0110: Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

The following are the Differentiating features between anthrax and anthracoid bacilli.

S.N. Characteristics Anthrax Bacilli Anthracoid Bacilli
1. Motility Non-Motile Generally Motile
2. Capsule Capsulated Non-Capsulated
3. Shape Grow in long chains Grow in short chains
4. Medusa Head Colony Present Not Present
5. Growth in Penicillin Agar (10 units/ml) No Growth Grow Usually
6. Hemolysis Hemolysis absent or weak. Usually well marked
7. Gelatin Liquefaction Slow Gelatin Liquefaction Rapid Gelatin Liquefaction
8. Turbidity No Turbidity in broth Turbidity usually
9. Salicin Fermentation Negative Usually Positive
10. Growth at 45°C No Growth Grows usually
11. Chloral Hydrate Growth inhibited by  Chloral Hydrate Not Inhibited
12. Gamma Phage Susceptible to gamma phage Not susceptible
13. Pathogenesis Pathogenic to laboratory animals Not pathogenic

questions.text: 174. A 3-year-old child presents with an upper limb deformity as given in the image below. He has had recurrent respiratory infections and is breathless while walking. You hear a wide split and fixed second heart sound through all phases of respiration. Identify the heart disease likely to be present in this child.
questions.solution:
The heart disease likely to be present in this child is an atrial septal defect (ASD).

The given clinical history along with the image is suggestive of Holt Oram syndrome. The syndrome is characterized by hypoplasia of the thumb, phocomelia, atrial septal defect, and triphalangism. 

Clinical features of ASD include exercise intolerance and failure to thrive although many children are asymptomatic. On auscultation, there is a widely split and fixed second heart sound in all phases of respiration, along with an ejection systolic murmur. Occasionally an ejection click is heard over the pulmonary area.

Chest X-ray shows enlarged right atrium and right ventricle. The diagnosis can be further affirmed in ECG which interprets right ventricular volume overload with normal peripheral vascular resistance. The location and size of the ASD can be confirmed in 2D scanning of the defect. Treatment involves closure of the defect either by surgery or by percutaneous catheter device insertion over the defect. 

Other options:

Option B: Transposition of great vessels (TGV) - ejection systolic murmur of grade 1 or 2 with features of cyanosis and failure to thrive.

Option C: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) - continuous murmur is distinctly heard on auscultation due to systolic and diastolic overloading of the pulmonary artery. 

Option D Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - pulmonary ejection systolic murmur with a tricuspid flow murmur.

questions.text: 175. During routine USG examination of a G2P1L1 woman, you note findings suggestive of placenta increta. What is the pathology involved in this condition?

choices.text: Villi are attached to lower uterine segment

questions.solution:
In placenta increta, the chorionic villi invade the myometrium.

Accreta syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. These occur due to:

* Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 

* Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

The various types of morbidly adherent placenta (Placenta accreta spectrum) are:

Types of Placenta accreta spectrum (PAS)

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa




Note: Villi are attached to the lower uterine segment in placenta previa.

Investigations that help in diagnosing these conditions:

* USG

* Color Doppler 

* MRI 

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta spectrum are:

* Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between the uterus and the placenta

* Placental vascular lacunae

* Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

The image below shows placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

questions.text: 176. According to Casper's dictum, which of the following is correct with respect to the rate of decomposition of a body in air, water, and soil?
questions.solution:
Casper dictum states that a body decomposes in air twice as rapidly as in water, and eight times as rapidly as in earth. Therefore, the rate of decomposition is Air > Water > Soil. It is helpful in the estimation of time since death.  

Free access of air hastens putrefaction, partly because the air conveys organisms to the body. Putrefaction is rapid in a body buried in a damp, marshy or shallow grave without clothes or coffin, because the body is exposed to constant changes of temperature. Putrefaction is more rapid in warm, fresh water than in cold, salt water. It is more rapid in stagnant water than in running water.

Note: Forensic taphonomy is the study and interpretation of postmortem processes of human remains i.e. the history of a body following death.

The ratio of the time a body takes to decompose in air, water, and soil is 1:2:8. This means that the time taken by soil is greater than water and air. So, the correct order of time taken for decomposition is Soil > Water > Air. But, in this question, the rate of decomposition is asked, therefore, it is faster in air followed by water and soil i.e, Air > Water > Soil. (Note - Greater than is denoted by '>' and Less than is denoted by '<' i.e the opening is towards the higher side)

questions.text: 177. In addition to dopamine antagonism, quetiapine has which of the following pharmacological properties?
questions.solution:
Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that blocks 5-HT1A, 5-HT2, D2, α1, α2, and H1 receptors in the brain.

Quetiapine has low D2 blocking activity and therefore extrapyramidal and hyperprolactinemic side effects are less. However, there is an increased risk of metabolic side effects due to serotonin antagonism.

Other options:

Option B: Phenelzine is an example of monoamine oxidase inhibitor.

Option C: Antidepressants work by inhibiting norepinephrine reuptake.

Option D: Aripiprazole has partial dopamine agonistic activity.
