Metabolic syndrome, Diabetes
Clozapine, Olanzapine
Aripiprazole, Ziprasidone
Weight gain
Clozapine, Olanzapine
Aripiprazole, Haloperidol
Hyperprolactinemia
Amisulpride, Haloperidol, Risperidone
Aripiprazole, Quetiapine
Clozapine, Olanzapine- almost zero risk (mild risk)
Extrapyramidal effects
Haloperidol
Clozapine, Quetiapine


Pearl PM0526: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation


 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation
Amisulpride Hyperprolactinemia
Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia

questions.text: 178. A 36-year-old male presented to the OPD with purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins. Identify the lesion shown below that was found on the oral mucosa of this patient.
questions.solution:
Purplish, itchy, flat-topped bumps on his shins are suggestive of Lichen planus. White streaks forming a lacework in the buccal mucosa, as seen in the image, is a characteristic feature of lichen planus known as Wickham’s striae.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. The primary lesions of lichen planus are described by the characteristic "6 Ps": planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques. These well-defined areas of purple-coloured, itchy, flat-topped papules may be with interspersed lacy white lines known as Wickham's striae. It may present with mucous membrane lesions in the absence of skin lesions, commonly involving the tongue and buccal mucosa.

Atrophy may mimic Wickham’s striae and leukoplakia, frictional keratosis and oral lichenoid eruptions are differentials. It must also be differentiated from erythroplakia and erythroleukoplakia by biopsy.

Other options:

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a distinct oral lesion on the lateral border of the tongue caused by EBV that typically occurs in immunocompromised patients. It appears as white, confluent patches of fluffy or hairy, hyperkeratotic thickenings, almost always on the lateral border of the tongue. Unlike Candida-caused oral thrush, the lesion cannot be rubbed away.

Option C: Frictional keratosis is caused by chronic irritation, particular lifestyle habits or infective agents. 

Option D: Oral lichenoid eruptions are due to chrome/cobalt prosthesis.

Pearl PM1995: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)



Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .



Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium



Image : Pup-tent sign 



Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: 179. Which of the following triggers the alternative and classical pathways of the complement system, respectively?
questions.solution:
The alternate pathway is activated by lipopolysaccharide and classical pathway by antibodies bound to antigen(immune complex) respectively.

The classical pathway, which is triggered by binding of C1 to antibody (IgM or IgG) that has combined with antigen.

The alternative pathway, which can be triggered by microbial surface molecules (e.g., endotoxin, or lipopolysaccharide [LPS]), complex polysaccharides, cobra venom, and other substances, in the absence of antibody.

The lectin pathway, in which plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes and directly activates C1.



Pearl PM1923: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency
C1, C2, C4 Immune- complex disease (SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1-inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema


Pearl PM0410: Functions of Complement



* Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.

* C5a is also a chemotactic agent.

* Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.

* Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: 180. A 60-year-old male with an Intertrochanteric fracture left femur, which was treated surgically with the following implant. Identify the implant.
questions.solution:
The image shows a dynamic condylar screw.

Dynamic condylar screw is a type of screw plate system. It was originally developed for distal femur fractures, but is also used for reverse oblique intertrochanteric and subtochanteric fractures.

The X-ray below shows a dynamic condylar screw in a patient.



Dynamic Hip Screw has a long cancellous screw which glides freely inside the sleeve of the side plate. It can be differentiated from a dynamic condylar screw by identifying the angle between the plate and the screw. It is usually 95 degrees in a dynamic condylar screw and 130 to 140 degrees in a dynamic hip screw. The image below shows a dynamic hip screw:



Interfragmentary screw, also called lag screw, is a type of screw that passes perpendicular and through the fracture surface to provide compression forces at the fracture site. The image of lag screw is shown below:



Self tapping screw has a pointed tip and sharp threads which does not require pre-preparation, or tapping,  of the drilled hole before insertion. The image of self tapping screw  is shown below:

questions.text: 181. Vaccination is an example of___________
questions.solution:
Vaccination is an example of artificial active immunity. It is acquired by injecting inactivated/killed/subunits of microorganisms to the host. This causes the host immune system to develop antibodies. 

Examples of other types of immunity: 

* Natural active immunity: Clinical or subclinical infection. 

* Artificial active immunity:Vaccination.

* Natural passive immunity: Transplacental transfer of antibody, colustrum.

* Artificial passive immunity: Anti-tetanus serum, anti-diphtherial serum. 

* Combined immunization: Antisera and vaccine are given at the same time

questions.text:
182. A 37-year-old woman presented with a fever and malaise. On examination, petechiae, a tender, pink nodule on her finger, and a cardiac murmur were appreciated. A probable diagnosis of bacterial endocarditis was made and the blood culture was positive for enterococci. Which of the following is true about enterococcus?

PYR: Pyrrolidinyl-beta-naphtylamide
questions.solution:
Enterococcus is non-hemolytic on blood agar.

Enterococcus belongs to the Streptococcaceae family and belongs to the Lancefield D group. Enterococcus includes organisms like E.fecalis, E.faecium, and E.durans. They are gram-positive oval cocci that are paired and are arranged at an angle to each other. 

Enterococcus species are generally non-hemolytic, although alpha or beta hemolysis is shown by some of the strains. They show growth in 6.5% sodium chloride, 40% bile, at a pH of 9.6, and in 0.1% methylene blue milk. It can cause urinary tract and biliary tract infections, endocarditis, and suppurative infections like an intra-abdominal abscess.

Other important characteristics of Enterococcus are:

* They are relatively heat-resistant

* They are PYR (pyrrolidinyl-beta-naphtylamide) test positive  (option B)

* Tiny magenta pink colonies are formed on MacConkey medium

* They ferment mannitol, sorbitol, sucrose, and esculin (option A)

* They produce black colonies on tellurite blood agar

Treatment: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for drug-resistant enterococcal infections.

Other options:

Option C- Optochin sensitivity is associated with Streptococcus pneumonia, while Viridans streptococci are optochin-resistant.

questions.text: 183. A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with a history of severe epigastric pain. She gives a history of self-medication with two tablets of ibuprofen daily for her joint pains. The doctor suspects a gastric ulcer. Which part of the stomach would be affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of epigastric pain in a patient with a history of chronic NSAID use suggests an NSAID-induced gastric ulcer. According to the Modified Johnson anatomic classification, NSAID-induced gastric ulcers are classified as Type V and may occur in any part/anywhere in the stomach. 

H. pylori and NSAIDs use are the most important factors in the development of Peptic ulcer disease. The most common sites for peptic ulcers are the first part of the duodenum and the lesser curvature of the stomach. NSAID-induced ulcers can occur anywhere in the stomach. 

NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes which form the rate-limiting step of prostaglandin synthesis in the GI tract. Prostaglandins promote gastric and duodenal mucosal protection via mucin and bicarbonate secretion and increased mucosal blood flow. NSAIDs impair these protective mechanisms, increasing the risk of peptic ulcers.

No dose of NSAID is completely safe. Most patients with NSAID-induced gastric ulcers present with complications such as ulcer perforation and bleeding without preceding dyspepsia symptoms. Concomitant use of glucocorticoids, anticoagulants, cigarette smoking, alcohol consumption, or concomitant H. Pylori infection increases the risk of complications in NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.

Modified Johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer:

Type Location Acid level
I Lesser curve at incisura Low to normal
II Gastric body with duodenal ulcer Increased
III Prepyloric Increased
IV High on lesser curve Normal
V Anywhere Normal, NSAID induced


Pearl PM1523: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure


 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: 184. A 32 year old woman presents with a swelling in her neck as shown below. The swelling is not associated with pain or movement on protrusion of the tongue. There was no evidence of lymphadenopathy on palpation and the swelling was non-transilluminant in nature. Based on the above findings, what potential diagnosis can be considered?
questions.solution:
This patient with painless swelling in the submandibular region not moving on deglutition and non-transilluminant in nature is most likely an epidermoid cyst. 

Epidermoid cysts often exhibit a gradual and progressive rate of growth. Although they may be present from birth, they are commonly diagnosed around the second or third decade of life. The masses are characterized by their painless nature and lack of symptoms, gradually growing in size.

The typical anatomical locations for the presence of these structures are the orbit, calvarial diploic space, and intracranial region. Typically, they are situated in the midline, either above or below the mylohyoid muscle. The management of epidermoid cysts located in the floor of the mouth typically involves surgical intervention, which can be performed either intraorally or extraorally. The choice of approach depends on factors such as the specific location and size of the cyst.

Other options:

Option A: Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells. The inner layer contains columnar cells, while the outer layer contains cuboidal cells. They are almost always seen in the parotid glands.

Option B: Ludwig's angina is the infection of the floor of the mouth. The submandibular space is present between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia that extends between the hyoid bone and the mandible on the other side. The mylohyoid muscle divides this space into the sublingual space (above the mylohyoid) and the submaxillary and submental compartments (below the mylohyoid). 

The patient usually presents with odynophagia, trismus, a swollen floor of the mouth with a woody-hard feel, and the tongue is pushed up and back is likely to have Ludwig's angina. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections.



Option C: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct. Clinically, the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and often transilluminant.

questions.text: 185. Which of the following is not included in the exclusion criteria for systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA)?

choices.text: Psoriasis or a history of psoriasis

questions.solution:
Generalized lymph node enlargement is included in the definition of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA) and not in the exclusion criteria for sJIA. 

Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks, Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of 

* Evanescent erythematous rash that is non-pruritic and migratory with lesions lasting<1 hr.

* Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly

* Generalized lymphadenopathy

* Serositis

Exclusion criteria for systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA)

* Psoriasis or a history of psoriasis in the patient or a 1st-degree relative

* Arthritis in an HLA-B27–positive boy beginning after the 6th birthday

* Ankylosing spondylitis, enthesitis-related arthritis, sacroiliitis with inflammatory bowel disease, Reiter syndrome, or acute anterior uveitis, or a history of one of these disorders in a 1st-degree relative

* Presence of  Rheumatoid factor on at least two occasions at least 3 months apart

The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-

* Oligoarthritis (4 or fewer joints) (Most common type)

* Polyarthritis (5 or more joints) RF Positive

* RF Negative

* Systemic JIA

* Psoriatic arthritis

* Enthesitis-related arthritis

* Undifferentiated

questions.text: 186. A 26-year-old male presented with the following clinical findings after he sustained an injury to his leg in a road traffic accident 2 days ago. There is no neurovascular deficit on examination. An X-ray revealed a proximal tibial fracture. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Open reduction and K wire fixation

questions.solution:
This is a case of closed proximal tibia fracture with soft tissue complications such as haemorrhagic fracture blisters as shown in the image. Due to superficial soft tissue compromise, the best option for treatment in this patient is skeletal stabilization with external fixation. 

This procedure stabilizes the fracture enough to prevent complications due to hypermobility at the fracture site, like neurovascular injury and compartment syndrome. It also gives enough time and space for the soft tissue to heal. After the soft tissue has recovered adequately, open reduction and internal fixation can be planned as a second surgery at a later stage.

Other options:

Option B: Skeletal stabilization with plaster cast is not the treatment of choice as it hinders soft tissue healing. 

Option C, D: Open reduction with plate fixation and Open reduction and K-wire fixation cannot be performed at this stage due to soft tissue compromise, as it increases the chances of osteomyelitis, non-union, scar dehiscence.

questions.text: 187. You notice a patient lying in the hospital compound with his attendant, to be seen by a psychiatrist. He does not react when you lend him a hand to make him stand. He doesn't move or respond to any other instruction given by the attendant. This behavior can be best described as:
questions.solution:
The behavior of not responding to commands and external stimuli is known as negativism.

Negativism is a feature seen in catatonia. Verbal or nonverbal opposition to suggestions or advice is exhibited. There is resistance to efforts to be moved and the patient might even do the opposite of what is asked.

Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. It is a new diagnostic category in the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5). A diagnosis of catatonia is not made if there is a primary mental disorder such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if present during the course of delirium. 

Abnormal behaviors include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing. Waxy flexibility is characterized by uniform resistance offered to passive positioning. Catalepsy is a passive inducted posture that is maintained against gravity by the patient. 

Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. It can also be seen in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

The primary treatment for catatonia includes identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed. Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of catatonia temporarily. Electroconvulsive therapy should be started for catatonia that is not responding to benzodiazepines and in severe cases with life-threatening conditions such as refusal to eat. 

Other options:

Option A: Mannerisms are normal movements that look odd and are involuntary. 

Option B: Stereotypy is purposeless repetitive speech or movements.

Option D: Echopraxia is characterized by mimicking an observed movement.

Pearl PM0498: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

* Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.

* Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

* Treatment-resistant depression

* Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)

* Depression with psychotic features

* Depressed suicidal pregnant women

* Refusal to eat or drink

* Imminent risk for suicide

* Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

* Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia

* Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

* Retrograde amnesia (most common)

* Partial anterograde amnesia

* Disorientation

* Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

* Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction

* Space occupying brain lesion

* Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

Pearl PM0340: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

* Risperidone

* Olanzapine

* Quetiapine

* Aripiprazole

* Ziprasidone

* Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

* Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.

* Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.

* Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.

* All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.text: 188. Which of the following describes degloving injury?

choices.text: Skin is stripped off the subcutaneous tissue
Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped off the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia stripped off underlying muscle
Muscle also is stripped off leaving exposed bone

questions.solution:
Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped by avulsion from its underlying fascia, leaving the neurovascular structures, tendon or bone exposed.

Degloving injury can be either open or closed.

* Open degloving injury- ex: Ring avulsion injury with the loss of finger skin.

* Closed degloving injury- ex: Roll over injury caused by motor vehicle.

Investigation for checking viability of skin:

* Examination under UV light after injection of flourescein.

* Serial excision until punctate dermal bleeding is obvious.

Image: Degloving injury

questions.text: 189. A 25-year-old man who recently visited a forest reserve in Karnataka presented with sudden onset of headache, myalgia, fever, and severe prostration. He was diagnosed to have Kyasanur Forest disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

choices.text: It is caused by a virus of Flaviviridae family
It is a transmitted by Haemaphysalis spinigera
Monkeys serve as the amplifier of infection
The disease spreads on contact with an infected patient

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Kyasanur Forest disease (KFD) is that the disease spreads on contact with an infected patient. No person-to-person transmission is described in KFD. 

Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral infection caused by Kyasanur forest disease virus (KFDV), a member of the virus family Flaviviridae. It is transmitted by the bite of hard ticks, Haemaphysalis spinigera being the principal vector, which also acts as a reservoir. It was endemic to the forests of Karnataka but now has also been detected in neighbouring states of Tamil Nadu and Kerala.

Transmission to humans usually occurs after a tick bite or contact with an infected animal (a sick or recently dead monkey). Monkeys act as amplifier hosts. Forest birds and small mammals are the reservoir hosts.

The clinical features include constitutional symptoms like fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, hemorrhagic symptoms, and severe prostration. The diagnosis is established via PCR, virus isolation from blood, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent serologic assay.

A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.

The ecological cycle of Kyasanur forest disease is given below.



Pearl PM1731: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: 190. An elderly patient presents with weight loss, loss of appetite, and an ill-defined epigastric mass. There is an associated palpable periumbilical nodule on examination. Identify the most likely precursor to this presentation.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly patient presenting with weight loss, loss of appetite, an ill-defined epigastric mass, and a palpable periumbilical nodule (the pathognomic Sister Joseph's nodule) is suggestive of gastric cancer. The most likely precursor to the development of this condition is chronic atrophic gastritis.

Gastric cancer is the fourth most common cancer type and a leading cause of cancer death worldwide. Gastric adenocarcinoma is the most common of all gastric cancers. Based on the gross appearance, it is classified into two types:

* Diffuse: characterized by gastric wall thickening due to infiltrates

* Intestinal: associated with malignant masses composed of glandular structures

Patients present with unexplained weight loss, loss of appetite, abdominal discomfort, nausea, vomiting, and upper GI bleeding. An epigastric abdominal mass may be present, and it indicates a large primary tumor, liver metastasis, or carcinomatosis. A palpable umbilical nodule (Sister Joseph’s nodule) is characteristic of advanced disease. A rectal exam may reveal hard nodularity indicating metastases (described as the shelf of Blumer) in the pouch of Douglas.

Chronic atrophic gastritis is the most common precursor for gastric cancer, particularly the intestinal subtype. It is more common in the elderly but can also be seen in young patients in areas with a high incidence of gastric cancer. Underlying Helicobacter pylori infection is critical in the pathogenesis of atrophic gastritis. There are three distinct patterns described:

* Autoimmune: involving the acid-secreting proximal stomach

* Hypersecretory: involving the distal stomach

* Environmental: involving multiple random areas

Other options:  Option A and B: Hyperplastic polyp and chronic peptic ulcer may lead to the development of gastric cancer, but this association is rare.

Option D: Inflammatory polyps have very little to no malignant potential.

Pearl PM1068: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

* Dietary

* Low fat or protein consumption

* Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content

* High complex carbohydrate consumption

* Smoking, alcohol consumption

* Spicy food, high salt diet

* Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables

* Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency

* Genetic and familial

* E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer

* Blood group A

* FAP

* Li-Fraumeni syndrome

* HNPCC

* BRCA 2 mutation

* Premalignant lesions

* Chronic atrophic gastritis

* Adenomatous polyp (FAP)

* Pernicious anemia

* Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)

* Menetrier’s disease

* Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ

* Others

* Low socioeconomic status

* Male gender

* Rubber and coal workers

* EBV infection

Pearl PM1853: Types of Chronic gastritis

Type A and Type B

  Type B (90% cases) Type A (10% cases)
Association Helicobacter pylori

Autoimmune disease
Site Antral Predominant Fundus and body with antral sparing
Acid Production Normal to increased Decreased (achlorhydria)
Gastrin Normal to increased Increased (hypergastrinemia)
HLA No association HLA DR3, HLA B8
Serology Antibodies to H. pylori

Sensitive: Anti-parietal antibodies

Specific: Anti-IF antibodies
Cytokines involved

IL-1, IL-8

 No
Long term sequelae

Non-atrophic pan gastritis- MALTOMA

Atrophic pan gastritis-Adenocarcinoma

Peptic ulcer

 

Diffuse atrophy,

Pernicious anemia,

Adenocarcinoma,

Gastric carcinoid tumors
Histology

Intraepithelial neutrophils,

Subepithelial plasma cells

 Lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages
Other associated lesion

Hyperplastic/inflammatory polyps

 Neuroendocrine hyperplasia
Association Low socioeconomic status, poverty, residence in rural areas Autoimmune diseases like thyroiditis, diabetes mellitus, Graves disease

questions.text: 191. A 25-year-old man presents with diarrhoea and abdominal pain for the past 15 days after eating biriyani at a restaurant. Which of the following tests best helps distinguish between an inflammatory or a non-inflammatory etiology of this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
The faecal lactoferrin agglutination assay test is the best test to distinguish between inflammatory and non-inflammatory causes of acute diarrhoea, owing to a very high sensitivity and specificity of 90%.

Diarrhoea lasting for less than 2 weeks is defined as acute diarrhoea. (According to Harrison's 21st edition, CMDT mentions
Diarrhoea can be broadly characterized as the excretion of unusually liquid or unformed faeces with an increased frequency. In the context of individuals adhering to a standard Western diet, a stool weight above 200 g per day can generally indicate diarrhoea. Typically, healthcare professionals define diarrhoea as a condition characterized by an elevated number of bowel movements (exceeding three per day) or the presence of loose or watery stool consistency.

Diarrhoea can be classified into three categories based on its duration: acute, persistent, and chronic. Acute diarrhoea refers to cases lasting less than two weeks, while persistent diarrhoea lasts between two and four weeks. Chronic diarrhoea is characterised by a duration beyond four weeks.

Other options:

Option B: With a sensitivity and specificity of 70% and 50% respectively, faecal leukocytes are a poor indicator of an inflammatory aetiology of diarrhoea.

Option C: The incidence of positive stool cultures in cases of acute diarrhoea is generally quite low, except in individuals with very severe disease. 

Option D: The stool guaiac test is also not as sensitive or specific as that of fecal lactoferrin to detect a difference between inflammatory and non-inflammatory diarrhoea.

questions.text: 192. The organism shown in the image, when detected in a water source indicates remote contamination. Identify the organism:
questions.solution:
The image shows Clostridium perfringens which is an indicator of remote contamination of water. 

Clostridium perfringens spores, though fewer in number than E. coli, survive longer in water and resist normal chlorination. Their presence, especially without coliforms, indicates remote faecal contamination. Microscopically, they appear as large, regularly brick-shaped, gram-positive bacilli without visible spores.

Faecal streptococci are also found in faeces and serve as confirmatory markers of recent contamination, especially in uncertain cases.

E. coli, a typical faecal coliform, is the primary indicator of water contamination due to its abundance in human intestines and ease of detection. Coliform testing is preferred because these organisms survive longer than pathogens and are easier to identify.

questions.text: 193. A 66-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of cough, increased thirst, and increased urination. Chest X-ray revealed a central mass arising in the right lung field. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). FNAC of the tumour is done as shown. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with SIADH, a central mass in the right lung field and FNAC showing basophilic cells with salt and pepper chromatin suggests the most probable diagnosis to be small cell carcinoma lung. 

Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. Confirmation can be done by IHC and detection of neurosecretory granules in the cells.

questions.text: 194. A male patient presented with a chronic, progressively enlarging, indurated ulcer on his left hand for the past 1 month. He says that he takes bath daily in a pond. A diagnosis of Buruli ulcer is suspected. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is endemic to tropical wetlands.
It is caused by Mycobacterium marinum.
Rifampicin and streptomycin are used for treatment.

questions.solution:
Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. Mycobacterium marinum causes swimming pool granuloma/ fish tank granuloma.

Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans - a fastidious, slow-growing bacterium. 

It is closely associated with tropical wetlands, and transmission occurs via mosquitoes and aquatic biting arthropods.

It is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue. It is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. 

The image given below shows a Buruli ulcer.



It can also manifest as a subcutaneous nodule, plaque, or an aggressive edematous infection of the soft tissue. Ulcers are usually seen on the legs or arms. They heal with disfiguring scars. Regional lymph nodes are not involved; no systemic invasion.

 

The smear from the edge of the ulcer shows large clumps of acid-fast bacilli.

 

Treatment:

* Duration: 8 weeks

* Antibiotics:

* Rifampicin plus streptomycin

* Rifampicin plus clarithromycin

* Rifampicin plus moxifloxacin

* Surgical debridement, skin grafting, wound care.

questions.text: 195. You are an intern posted in medicine OPD. A 58-year-old man comes with palpable organomegaly till below the umbilicus (corresponding to level 5 in the given image). Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of the given finding?
questions.solution:
The given finding corresponds to massive splenomegaly. Typhoid does not cause massive splenomegaly. It may cause mild to moderate splenomegaly.

Massive splenomegaly is defined as a spleen palpable 8 cm below the costal margin or weighing 1000 g. Some authors even classify it to be massive if it extends till the umbilicus or further.

Causes of massive splenomegaly include:

* Chronic myeloid leukemia

* Gaucher’s disease

* Lymphomas

* Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

* Hairy cell leukaemia

* Sarcoidosis

* Myelofibrosis with myeloid metaplasia

* Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia

* Polycythemia vera

* Diffuse splenic hemangiomatosis

questions.text: 196. Identify the helminth from the given life cycle:
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm).

Humans are the definitive host. They get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops. Larvae come out once the cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults.

The fertilized female worm grows and migrates within the connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water, like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes blister formation. The blister ruptures, discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1-stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host, freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

Other options:

Option A: Wuchereria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:



Option B: The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.



Option D:  Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors.

questions.text: 197. In a study, group A received a placebo while Group B received a new drug. In group A, 36 deaths were reported out of a sample of 120. In group B, 26 deaths were reported out of a sample size of 130. Calculate the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) value.
questions.solution:
The value of Absolute Risk Reduction(ARR) in the given question is 10%.

 

The ARR(Absolute Risk Reduction) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo group and the drug group. The absolute risk rate is usually expressed in percentages. Here, the Absolute Risk rate is given as No. of deaths/Sample population) x 100.

 

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculation of absolute risk rate

The absolute risk rate in group A (placebo)

= (36/120)x 100

= 30%

 

The absolute risk rate in group B (new drug)

= (26/130)x 100

= 20%

 

Step 2: Calculation of absolute risk reduction (ARR)

ARR = Absolute risk rate in group A - Absolute risk rate in group B

= 30 - 20

= 10%

 

Therefore the Absolute Risk Reduction in Group B as compared to the placebo group is 10%.

The Absolute Risk Reduction(ARR) signifies the proportion of people who benefited from the new treatment/intervention over the existing treatment/placebo.

questions.text: 198. Which of the following proteins is involved in the absorption of calcium in the intestine?
questions.solution:
Calbindin is involved in the absorption of calcium (Ca2+) in the intestine.

Ca2+ is transported across the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells via channels known as transient receptor potential vanilloid type 6 (TRPV6) and binds to an intracellular protein known as calbindin-D.

Calbindin sequesters the absorbed calcium so that it does not disturb epithelial signalling processes that involve calcium. The absorbed Ca2+ is thereby delivered to the basolateral membrane of the epithelial cell, from where it can be transported into the bloodstream by either a sodium/calcium exchanger (NCX1), Ca2+ - Mg2+ ATPase, or PMCA1b .

The overall transport process is regulated by 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.

questions.text: 199. A child presented to OPD with frequent vomiting, failure to thrive, lethargy, protein aversion, and intellectual disability. On evaluation, he is found to have raised blood ammonia levels and very high levels of plasma citrulline. Which is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
Argininosuccinate synthetase is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby.

 

The deficiency of the Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, also called classic citrullinemia.  The severe or neonatal form (the most common form) appears in the 1st few days of life with signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia. In the subacute or mild form, clinical findings such as failure to thrive, frequent vomiting, developmental delay, and dry, brittle hair appear gradually after 1 year of age.

 

Laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency, except that the plasma citrulline concentration is greatly elevated (option D). Urinary excretion of orotic acid is moderately increased. The diagnosis is confirmed by DNA analysis.

 

Other options:

Option A: In the near-complete enzymatic deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1, symptoms appear during the 1st few days or even hours of life. The baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsions, coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. Orotic aciduria and increased production of pyrimidines like uracil, in this case, are not seen in Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency.

Option C: Arginase deficiency is a rare distal urea cycle disorder that presents as an acute neonatal form with intractable seizures, cerebral oedema, and death. Laboratory findings include marked elevations of arginine in plasma and CSF.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 200. ‘Lead time’ refers to the time between:

choices.text: Disease onset and first critical diagnosis
Disease onset and first possible point of detection
First possible point of detection and final critical point
First possible point of detection and usual time of diagnosis

questions.solution:
Lead time refers to the time between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the time gained by screening. Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis. Early detection of disease will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

The final critical point is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.



Lead time bias occurs when a disease is detected by a screening or surveillance test at an earlier time point than it would have been if it had been diagnosed by its clinical appearance. If survival time is measured from the time of diagnosis, then there is an apparent increased survival time in the screened patients.

For example, a CT scan of the chest identifies a malignant tumor of the lung earlier than a traditional chest x-ray. However, early treatment does not significantly enhance overall survival in patients with lung cancer. Therefore, any apparent improvement in the 5-year survival rates of patients diagnosed through a CT scan compared to those diagnosed with an X-ray is attributed to lead-time bias. 

Screening time is the time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the final critical point of diagnosis.
